CATEGORY: WTF?

-----
BODY:
<p>
From <a href="http://news.com.com/2100-1001-960933.html?tag=fd_top" title="Article about the arrest of a hacker"><cite>News.com</cite></a> : 
</p>

<blockquote>
<p>
A Russian hacker lured to the United States by the FBI under the ruse of a job interview is sentenced to three years in prison for computer crime ... The computers they used had software on them that logged every keystroke and FBI agents were able to <strong>later grab the men's passwords and download evidence off their computer network in Russia ... The FBI countered, and the judge agreed, that Russian law does not apply to the agents' actions. </strong>.
</p>
</blockquote>

<p>
So let me get this shit straight,  someone from Russia can break an American law while in Russia, and we can nab him, but Americans can break Russian laws while in America and we're somehow not guilty of anything?
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
This is what really pisses me off about this country; the whole do as I say not as I do mentality with our government and Hollywood.
</p>
<p>
This is just as bad as the <a href="http://www.freesklyarov.org/">Dmitry Sklyarov</a> case where be nabbed him in the US for breaking some Abobe eBook encryption while in Russia, where it's NOT illegal to do so.
</p>
<p>
Any bets on <a href="http://www.onlinereporter.com/#audiobooksforfree.com%20Director%20Breaks%20Microsoft%20Reader" title="Article about cracking Microsoft eReader">who's going to be next</a>?
</p>

<p>
From <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/usatonline/20021003/4503669s.htm"><cite>USA Today</cite></a> :
</p>
<p>
No, it's not the story that I find interesting. Well, I <em>do</em> find the story interesting, but it's what I always don't find at the end of these stories on news sites: No friggin links related to the topic of the story. Bastards.
</p>
<p>
So I read an article an article about some homeless guys blog. Wouldn't it be nice to read it? Sure, if I could find it from reading the story. Of course, the marvels of <a href="http://www.google.com/search?q=Homeless+Guy+Weblog" title="Google search for the homeless blogger"><cite>Google</cite></a> will get me there quickly, but for the love of god, it's the internet. It's all about the links. So <a href="http://thehomelessguy.blogspot.com/" title="The homeless guy's blog">here ya go</a>, this one's on me. :-/
</p>

</p>

<blockquote>
<p>
LOS ANGELES - The Recording Industry Association of America filed a $7.1 billion lawsuit against the nation's radio stations Monday, accusing them of freely distributing copyrighted music.
</p>
<p>... "It's criminal," RIAA president Hilary Rosen said. "Anyone at any time can simply turn on a radio and hear a copyrighted song...
</p>
</blockquote>

<p>
Here's the sad part: seeing this headline in a real newspaper would not surprise me one little bit. Especially when you have people like Jamie Kellner, CEO of Turner Broadcasting claiming that <a href="http://action.eff.org/action/moreinfo.asp?item=1517" title="Article about commercials and stealing">not watching commercials is stealing</a>.
</p>
<p>
When are these people going to learn that one day, pissing off all of your customers by treating them like criminals is going to land them in deep sheep doo.
</p>

TITLE: Geek Porn
BASENAME: geek-porn
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Hardware
CATEGORY: Hardware
DATE: 10/07/2002 08:13:35 PM

BODY:
<p>
If there were such a thing as 'geek' porn, <a href="http://www.powernotebooks.com/5620_Pics.php3" title="Sager 5660 details page">this page</a> and <a href="http://www.powernotebooks.com/5660specs.php3" title="Sager 5560 details page">this page</a> surely would be part of it IMHO. Look at all those geeky specs and definitions! :-)
</p>
<p>
About 2 months ago, my Compaq Presario 18XL380 kicked the bucket. Apparently, the power jack felt the need to liberate itself from the motherboard. At the time, this turned out to be a blessing in disguise: Until Today.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<img src="/blog/images/hardware/np5660.jpg" width="247" height="227" alt="Sager NP5660 Picture" /><br />2.8GHz P4, 1GB Ram, ATI Mobility Radeon 9000. Wow.
</p>

<h4>Update</h4>
<p>
One NP5660 on it's way!. Ships Monday, should arrive on Wednesday. Review forthcoming after arrival.
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
Like all true geeks, I have more than one computer; 9 to be precise. Yes, <b>nine</b> computers about the office, 10 if you count the laptop the woman has which techically is mine. :-)
</p>

<ul>
<li>three(3) 1U FreeBSD servers</li>
<li>one(1) 4U FreeBSD server</li>
<li>one(1) HP Pavillion771n running XP (for games ok!)</li>
<li>one(1) built-like-a-tank Gateway NT4 server</li>
<li>one(1) HP Vectra Xm FreeBSD mail hub</li>
<li>one(1) Apple Power MAcintosh G3 (Beige)</li>
<li>one(1) Compaq Presario 18XL380 (Deceased)</li>
</ul>

<p>
Still not convinced?
</p>

<p class="image">
	<img src="/blog/images/hardware/server_rack.jpg" width="321" height="612" alt="Server Rack Photo" />
</p>
<p>
Now here is where the reasoning starts to fall apart after a truely sad chain of geek events.
</p>
<p>
First I bought the 1U rack servers in the hopes of converting away from the Gateway NT4 server towards Unix. The more I see MicroShaft in action, the less pleased I am about seeing a WinHozed box in my presence.
</p>
<p>
Then I converted my old desktop (Dual P3 450) into a 4U file server. Gotta have a place for <del>the porn and MP3 files right?...umm...I mean</del> the server backups and important files. :-) 
</p>
<p>
After that started, I spent a lot of time in the living room in front of the television with the notebook on my lap. Surfin. Hackin. Codin. Surfin. Flipping channels.  Watchin Alton Brown. You know the routine. Unfortunately, that also means I was getting no real work done.
</p>
<p>
Then the laptop croaked. The warranty had expired a year ago, and the only recourse was to pay Compaq for a new motherboard. NOT. So back to the Pavilion in the office I go. By now I'm finally getting work done. Converting to Unix. Surfin.  Codin. Playin <a href="http://www.lucasarts.com/products/outcast/" title="JKII home page">Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast</a>. But I digress.
</p>
<p>
But then today I ran across the specs for the new <a href="http://www.powernotebooks.com/5660specs.php3">Sager NP5660</a> and about dropped a load in me shorties. For the a lot less than what IBM, Dell, or Alien Ware wanted for the same (usually slower) specs, I'm getting one bitching machine that blows most desktops out of the water.
</p>
<p>
I'll do a full write up and review when she get's here, which should be around Monday of next week.
</p>

<a href="http://www.movabletype.org/25/">MoveableType 2.5</a> has hit the streets! Check out the <a href="http://www.movabletype.org/25/#about25">What's New</a> and <a href="http://www.movabletype.org/docs/mtchanges.html">Changelog</a> pages for more info. Remember boys and girls, <strong>ALWAYS</strong> backup your data before attempting a software upgrade! By the grace of <a title="*  If anything can go wrong, it will" href="http://www.murphys-laws.com/murphy/murphy-laws.html" >St. Murphy</a>, both the development server and the live server upgrades were quick and painless. <acronym title="Read The Fucking Manual">RTFM</acronym>!
</p>
<p>
Congrats to Ben Trott and Mena Trott on another release, and for the love of Pete, please <a href="http://www.movabletype.org/donate.shtml" title="Donat to Movable Type">donate</a>!
</p>
<h4>I spoke to soon. :-)</h4>
<p>
When my blog does ping to moveabletype.org, my title displays the encoded apostrophe instead of just the apostrophe. My bet is a plain old fashioned case of Pilot Error(TM).
</p>
<h4>Update</h4>
<p>
Wow. Ben is one fast cookie. Email reply and problem fixed in less than 30 minutes. Sweet. We're still not ruling out Pilot Error(TM) though.  :-)
</p>

--------
AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Nice Design: Wired.com
BASENAME: nice-design-wiredcom
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 10/11/2002 05:38:10 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
From <a href="http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,55675,00.html" title="Article about Wired News redesign"><cite>Wired News</cite></a> :
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
Wired News has a different appearance, but the new design isn't just about look and feel. The site now complies with standards recommended by the World Wide Web Consortium for greater access to all users.
</p>
</blockquote>

<p class="image">
<a href="/blog/images/www/wired_screenshot_large.png"><img src="/blog/images/www/wired_screenshot_small.png" width="350" height="250"  alt="Wired.com Screenshot" /></a><br />
<span class="caption">Click for larger image.</span>
</p>
<p>
I've got mixed feelings about this one. I'm a programmer by trade, so I tend to see things like this in black and white. <acronym title="You can't lie to a compiler">It either compiles or it doesn't</acronym>. So on the one hand, when they say they've used W3C standards like XHTML and and CSS instead of crappy HTML3.2 and Tables, I say Bravo!
</p>
<p>
However, my first instinct was to run the page through the W3C validator, and to my dismay, it <a href="http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http://www.wired.com/" title="Validate wirednews.com">does not validate</a>. So, the programmer in me say they are NOT using standards because it doesn't validate as such.
</p>
<p>
<a href="http://www.zeldman.com/daily/1002a.html#wired" title="Zeldman's comments on redesign">Jeffrey Zeldman</a> brings up a few good points for people like me with that first reaction. He says
</p>

<blockquote>
<p>
"Hardcore standards geeks sometimes judge the intentions of a site's owners and creators based on one critieria only: does it validate? When a site fails to validate, some geeks infer that the people behind the site made no effort. As the Wired redesign makes clear, validation alone does not tell the full story. ... In short, do not confuse fundamentalism with evangelism, or necessarily equate lack of compliance with lack of care."
</p>
</blockquote>

<p>
I'm not quite sure I buy into the "3rd Part Software/Advertising Code" issue though. Now a days, we have these high tech things called <a href="http://sitescooper.org/tao_regexps.html" title="Link to regular expression how to">regular expressions</a> and find/replace to fix problems like that. :-)
</p>
<p>
He's right. Sometimes it's the measure of the effort, not the result that counts. Congrats to Wired News!
</p>
-----

BODY:
<p>
Woohoo! Another FreeBSD <a href="http://www.freebsd.org/releases/4.7R/announce.html" title="FreeBSD 4.7 release announcement">release</a> hits the pavement running.This can only mean one thing here at the ranch: another geek filled weekend of compiling and pizza for all!
</p>
<p>
This is how <em>real</em> geeks have fun on the weekends:
</p>

<pre>
<kbd>
$ cvsup stable-supfile
$ cd /usr/src
$ make buildworld
$ make installworld
$ make buildkernel
$ make installkernel
$ mergemaster
</kbd>
</pre>

<p>
Now doesn't that look like fun? Who needs bars and loud music when you can have this kind of excitement!
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: TrackBack Enabled
BASENAME: trackback-enabled
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 10/12/2002 12:31:40 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
My brain hurts. TrackBack is now enabled. My only complaint so far is that I can't [easily] modify the URL that get's sent in the TrackBack ping. What would you need to? Well, for starters, the <code>$MTCGIPath$</code> doesn't work to well for this site. I do all of my blogging under an SSL Client Certificate secured URL, but you are viewing this blog at a different URL. With a little work, that's not so bad.
</p>
<p>
One of my goals with this site was to start eating my own dog food so to speak. Make sure the pages validate. Make sure I'm seperating style from content.  Make sure font sizes are resizable instead of fixed pixil heights (still have to do that yet). And make sure that the URLS are human readable and don't change if I decide to switch server languages/platforms. <a href="http://www.alistapart.com/">A List Apart</a> has a good article called <a href="http://www.alistapart.com/stories/succeed/">How to Succed With URLs</a> that I think every CMS vendor needs to read. :-)
</p>

-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
For example, let's say I have an individual entry archive page you want to link to. The URL could be
</p>

<pre>
<code>
http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/archives/entries/000001/
</code>
</pre>

while the <em>real</em> page may be located at

<pre>
<code>
http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/archives/entries/000001.xsp
</code>
</pre>

<p>
So what happens if next year I want to move from using eXtensible Server Pages on Apache to using PHP on [shudder] Windows IIS?
Now the URL for the actual page above would change from
</p>

<pre>
<code>
http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/archives/entries/000001.xsp
</code>
</pre>

to

<pre>
<code>
http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/archives/entries/000001.php
</code>
</pre>

but the the URL used on my website and others links to that entry would still be

<pre>
<code>
http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/archives/entries/000001/
</code>
</pre>

<p>
Without the URL mapping, we would have a lot of broken links everywhere.
</p>
<p>
So what was my point again? Ah yes, TrackBacks.
</p>
<p>
TrackBack pings send the URL of the <em>real</em> page (i.e. <code>/000001.xsp</code>) instead of what we would really like people to use ( <code>/000001/</code> ). Ouch!
</p>
<p>
Time to start writing up a patch I guess. :-)
</p>
-----

<p>
The older I get, the more things I put on my mental list of things I never will, or should own. Why?  Well, just because. I'm a a computer programmer and a sysadmin. Before that I was a musician, and before that a teenager.  I know computers. I'm not a genius or an expert, but I'd like to think I know a little more than most about my areas of practice. When you talk geek to me about computers, I follow it quite well. If you try to talk to me about rebuilding and engine, I'm clueless. Kind of ironic considering <a href="http://www.summitracing.com/" title="Visit summitracing.com">where I work</a>.  :-)
</p>
<p>
They say part of being successful is to know your limits, admit them, and ask for help when necessary. I can't fix things (well), so I know when not to try. Always hire a professional. So with that in mind, here are the things I will never own, if for no other reason that for my safety:
</p>

<ul>
<li><strong>Guns</strong><p>I would shoot myself in the foot somehow. I like my toes to much.</p></li>
<li><strong>Chainsaw</strong><p>See Above. I like my legs to much.</p></li>
<li><strong>Circular Saw/Table Saw</strong><p>See above. I like my fingers to much.</p></li>
<li><strong>Wood Chipper</strong><p>Yup. See above.</p></li>
<li><strong>Pnuematic Nailer</strong><p>Once you've see an xray on TV of a skull with a nail it. Nuff said.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>
The funny part about most of those *saw things: I did 4 years of shop class in high school without incident. Go figure.
</p>

<p>
Well, I finally took the plunge and tweaked the stylesheet  to use relative font sizes with the help of 
<a href="http://diveintoaccessibility.org/day_26_using_relative_font_sizes.html" title="Article on using relative font sizes">this article</a> over at 
<a href="http://diveintoaccessibility.org/" title="Visit diveintoaccessibility.org">Dive Into Accessability</a>.
</p>
<p>
What I don't like so far:
</p>

<ul>
<li>The font size for most of the content uses small, which compared to the pixel sizes is somewhere between to small and to big.</li>
<li>The stylesheet used to pass the W3C validator with no errors and no warnings. here still are no errors, but a whole lot of warnings creeped in.</li>
<li>The layout gets crazy in Mozilla when I resize now. It never used to do that with pixel fonts sizes. Although, Mozilla would resize all fonts regarless of relative or fixed while IE wouldn't play nice.

</li>
</ul>

<p>
It all comes back to eating your own dog food again I guess. Something to change my mind about later go do with cookies/javascript selected stylesheets 
with the pixel sizes changed instead of being relative.
</p>
<p>
What do you think?
</p>
<h4>Update</h4>
<p>
Damn. The CSS validator does fine if I upload and specify the options, but it does't work in general from the Valid CSS links on this page. Time to ditch relative and go back to fixed. :-(
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: SSL Out The Wazoo
BASENAME: ssl-out-the-wazoo
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Security
CATEGORY: Security
DATE: 10/13/2002 08:45:09 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
	My brain hurts. No really. Being a true paranoid about all things security related, I decided to
	lock down the email server for the outside people who will be sending mail through it. Why? Well. In order to prevent
	being an <a href="http://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/0,,sid9_gci782509,00.html" title="Definition fo an Open Relay">Open Relay</a>, we want to require passwords 
	from people who want to send out email from our email server. These people will also be logging in 
	using <a href="http://searchwebservices.techtarget.com/sDefinition/0,,sid26_gci212805,00.html" title="Definition of POP3">POP3</a>
 	or <a href="http://searchwebservices.techtarget.com/sDefinition/0,,sid26_gci214022,00.html" title="Definition of IMAP">IMAP</a> to fetch their email.
</p>
<p>
	So what's the problem? Well, everytime you log in to a POP3 or IMAP server to fetch your email, or log in to an SMTP server to 
	send mail (assuming that SMTP server requires a password to send mail), 
	you are sending your password in <strong>plain text</strong>, <strong>unencrypted</strong> for the whole world to see!  Not good.
</p>
<p>
	What's the solution? Why 
	<a href="http://searchsecurity.techtarget.com/sDefinition/0,,sid14_gci343029,00.html" title="Definition of SSL/TLS">SSL/TLS</a> of course!
	And the nice part is, you don't have to fork cash over to Verisign just to get SSL certificates. 
	Become <a href="http://www.modssl.org/docs/2.8/ssl_faq.html#ToC29" title="How-To become your own ceritifcate authority">your own</a> <acronym title="Certificate Authority">CA</acronym>!
</p>
<p>
	Now, with the help of some HOW-TO docs on the net and a handy firewall or two, all external persons we wish to allow to send outgoing email 
	must use IMAP over SSL (IMAPS), POP3 over SSL (SPOP3), or TLS over SMTP in addition to their usual user names and passwords. Way cool, but not exactly easy.
</p>
<p>
	Here's a list of links that got me through it without killing someone or throwing a server out of the window:
</p>

	<ul>
		<li><a href="http://www.modssl.org/docs/2.8/ssl_howto.html">Mod_SSL Docs: Chapter 5</a></li>
		<li><a href="http://www.modssl.org/docs/2.8/ssl_faq.html">Mod_SSL Docs: Chapter 6</a></li>
		<li><a href="http://www.aet.tu-cottbus.de/personen/jaenicke/postfix_tls/doc/">Postfix/TLS Docs by Lutz Janicke</a></li>
		<li><a href="http://www.delouw.ch/linux/Postfix-Cyrus-Web-cyradm-HOWTO-test/html/cyrus-config.html">Configuring Cyrus IMAP</a></li>
	</ul>

-----

<p>
Someone in MicroShaft PR, please make him stop.#@!$%<br />
From an <a href="http://www.silicon.com/public/door?6004REQEVENT=&amp;REQINT1=55937&amp;REQSTR1=silicon.com" title="Interview with Craig Mundie">article</a> over at <a href="http://www.silicon.com/" title="Visit silicon.com">Silicon.com</a> :
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
Second thing, our product is a more complete product. <strong>We have a built-in application server that's well integrated - there is no such comparable notion in the Linux server. We have a directory server built in - there is no such comparable thing in Linux</strong>. The Linux client hardly runs any applications, except a bunch of shareware stuff that's not very good.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>
What MicroShaft calls 'incomplete' I call choice. Here's a crazy thought. Maybe I <em>don't want</em> the application server 'in' the OS. Maybe I want to use a different application server. No such comparable app server in Linux? Ever heard of <a href="http://jakarta.apache.org/tomcat/" title="Tomcat home page"><cite>Tomcat</cite></a>? No such comparable directory server in Linux? Ever heard of <a href="http://www.isc.org/products/BIND/" title="Bind home page"><cite>Bind</cite></a> and <a href="http://www.openldap.org/" title="OpenLDAP home page"><cite>OpenLDAP</cite></a>?
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
I think it's not complete,<strong>it's a poor value proposition versus Windows</strong>. It is a clone of an operating system. <strong>There has yet to be any innovation, new features or new capabilities out of the Linux platform</strong>. First they cloned Unix, and there are people working on cloning some of our stuff. But it's just a cloning operating system. That doesn't mean we can stand still - we have to push along. <strong>But I don't think anyone should expect anything innovative coming out of that world</strong>. There's no data to support that.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>
Brrring. Clue phone, it's for you. Nothing innovative? Poor value? By poor value he must mean doesn't need security-patched and rebooted every other day.
</p>
<p>
<strong><em>Unbelievable.</em></strong>
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Valid XHTML/CSS Links
BASENAME: valid-xhtmlcss-links
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 10/15/2002 12:14:43 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
Apparently the Valid <acronym title="eXtensible HyperText Markup Language">XHTML</acronym>/<acronym title="Cascading Style Sheets">CSS</acronym> buttons and links on this site are broken. I only noticed when checking out the site from behind a proxy. But here's the strange part. I works from behind the <a href="http://www.squid-cache.org/" title="Squid proxy home page">Squid proxy</a> I'm running here internally, but chokes when behind an MicroShaft Proxy 2.0 server elsewhere. Maybe it heard it's ears burning. :-)
</p>
<p>
Anyway, it looks like a problem with the AxKit stuff, and I've found a patch. I'm not sure I should be patching software at this hour though. :-P
</p>
<p>
For other seekers of the problem:
</p>
<p>
<textarea rows="15" cols="45">
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject: WebUtils taglib
From: xxx@xxxxxxxxx.xxx (Mark A. Hershberger)
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 10:35:46 -0500

Is there a reason that the WebUtils taglib looks at the "VIA:"
header rather than $r->hostname first?  When the request is
coming from a proxy, it yields incorrect results.

This patch fixes the problem (this against 1.3_90 instead of 1.4):

-- WebUtils.pm 8 Jun 2001 15:50:39 -0000       1.1.1.1
+++ WebUtils.pm 4 Oct 2002 15:29:12 -0000
@@ -60,9 +65,7 @@
 }
 
 sub request_host () {
-    my $hostname = Apache->header_in('Via');
-    $hostname =~ s/^[0-9.]+ //g;
-    $hostname =~ s/ .*//g;
+    my $hostname = Apache->request->hostname;
     $hostname ||= $ENV{HTTP_HOST};
     $hostname ||= Apache->header_in('Host');
     return $hostname;

Mark.


-- 
Find inner peace and ten thousand around you shall be saved.
		     -- St. Seraphim of Sarov
-------------------------------------------------------------------
</textarea>
</p>

<p>
Looks like it works here because I'm zapping/anonmizing proxy headers via the following line in squid.conf:
</p>
<pre>
<code>
anonymize_headers deny Referer Via X-Forwarded-For
</code>
</pre>

<p>
Well, that would explain it!
</p>
<h4>Updated</h4>
<p>
All fixed - in theory. At least no crashy crash on pagey load.
Looks like the patch fixes the problem.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Sager NP5660 Review
BASENAME: sager-np5660-review
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Hardware
CATEGORY: Hardware
DATE: 10/17/2002 02:37:55 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
	Well, it finally arrived! My brand new Sager NP5660, fully loaded.
	As promised, this is the start of my review of this beast.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<img src="/blog/images/hardware/np5660.jpg" alt="Photo of Sager NP5660 laptop" width="246" height="227" />
</p>
<p>
It was getting a little late by the time I finished this, so be gentle. :-)
</p>

<ins>
<p>
<strong>
Well, my <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000145/">NP5600 has suffered it's first casualty</a>. Nothing serious, just the AC adapter.
</strong>
</p>
</ins>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<h3>Sections</h3>

<ol>
<li><a href="#background">Background</a></li>
<li><a href="#specs">Specs</a></li>
<li><a href="#ordering">Ordering</a></li>
<li><a href="#shipping">Shipping</a></li>
<li><a href="#case">Case Design/Construction</a></li>
<li><a href="#setup">Setup/Install</a></li>
<li><a href="#video">Display/Video</a></li>
<li><a href="#performance">Performance</a></li>
<li><a href="#battery">Battery Life</a></li>
<li><a href="#heat">Heat/Noise</a></li>
<li><a href="#conclusions">Conclusions</a></li>
</ol>

<h4><a id="background">Background</a></h4>
<p>
As I've <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000007/" title="Post about ordering the Sager 5660">mentioned before</a>, my Compaq Presario 18XL380 died about 2 months ago.
The power jack decided that it had enough, and broke away from the motherboard, leaving me with a pile of spare parts shaped like a laptop.
Since the warranty had expired in December 2001, there was no way I was going to pay Compaq $600+ for another motherboard.
So I set about the task of researching what was out there and what features I could live with for the right price.
</p>
<p>
Compaq was out of the question again. I didn't much like IBM prices, Dell had a bad taste in my mouth after supporting them in college, but I did
like the HP I bought the woman for school. IT had a durable case design and we've had no problems with it so far. However, after the HPaq-ComP merger,
I wasn't having any real confidence in the current status of either brands laptop.
</p>
<p>
Eventually I stumbled across the AlienWare <a href="http://www.alienware.com/main/system_pages/area51-m.asp" title="ALienware Area 51M product detail page">Area51m</a>, and started to drool at the options.
Some more usenet grepping, and I found out about Sager,
<a href="http://www.sagernotebooks.com/">sagernotebooks.com</a>, and eventually the <a href="http://www.powernotebooks.com/5660specs.php3" title="Sager NP5660 Specs">Sager NP5660</a>
at <a href="http://www.powernotebooks.com/">powernotebooks.com</a>. I was a little hesitant to order from PowerNotebooks because of their "Cash Discount" stuff on the website,
but after even more reviews and all the info at <a href="http://www.resellerratings.com/" title="Reseller Ratings Website">Reseller Ratings</a>, I felt the most comfortable ordering from PowerNotebooks.
I could have save a few bucks here and there with Discount Laptops, but better safe than sorry.
</p>



<h4><a id="specs">Specs</a></h4>
<p>
I ordered the Sager NP5660 Supra with the following options:
</p>

<ul>
<li>P4 2.8GHz CPU</li>
<li>40GB Ultra ATA/100 Hard Drive at 5,400 RPM</li>
<li>1024MB PC2100 DDR Memory</li>
<li>UXGA (1600 x 1200) TFT Active Matrix LCD Display w/ ATI Radeon Mobility 9000 w/ 64MB</li>
<li>Combo 8X DVD/16x10x24 CD-RW</li>
<li>Extra 24X CD ROM Module</li>
<li>3 Additional Years Extended Warranty</li>
<li>UPS 2nd Day Shipping</li>
</ul>

<p>
	Considering my last (still fixable) laptop croaked out of warranty, and the price of this new one, I would be insane to have not gotten the additional warranty.
</p>



<h4><a id="ordering">Ordering</a></h4>
<p>
Ordering was painless. I ordered on Wednesday, October 8th, 2002. I'm used to ordering things online, so fessing up that kind of bling over the net doesn't really phase me.
I opted to used my credit card instead of a money order because a) I'm lazy, and b) I wanted the security of a card purchase in case I
had to stop payment, of make and claims against the purchase w/ the credit card company. Just a little more leverage if needed over a money order.
</p>
<p>
Within a few hours, someone from PowerNotebooks called to make sure it was actually me placing the order. I love when companies do that. That way they ward of fraud
and I don't end up with a bill for 3 big ones with no idea who placed the order and where it went. By the end of the day, the payment stuff was completed and taken care of
and I had email receipts in hand. I fired off an email inquiring about the ship date of the computer. I was told that the laptop would ship on Monday, October 14th, 2002, and that
I should have it Wednesday, October 16th, 2002. Not bad. Not bad at all.
</p>
<p>
On Monday, I sent another email just to make sure it was shipping. Both me and the woman work and she goes to school full time, so there rarely anyone here to accept packages.
The were a chance that if I knew what day it would be here, I'd just scam a vacation day and play with the new toy. Donald returned my email promptly and told me that I was misinformed
and that the laptop would ship either Tuesday or Wednesday.
Apparently they were just a tad behind due to the dock workers strike on the west coast. No big deal really. These things happen. It actually turned out to be good as the 5400RPM hard drives were going to
become available Tuesday, so I upgraded to the faster drive and sprung the extra $15 for the Next Day Air Saver shipping. :-)
</p>
<p>
Let me just say that I'm really impressed with PowerNotebooks at this point. Try calling Dell or IBM and changing your order the day of or the day before it ships.
I bet it doesn't go so well, or as easily as it did with PowerNotebooks. Donald was  very helpfull and understanding, and kept me informed whenever possible.
</p>


<h4><a id="shipping">Shipping</a></h4>
<p>
On Tueday, I got an email from Donald letting me know that the laptop had shipping and that I would probably get it long before they got a tracking number for it.
Next Day Air Saver has guaranteed deliver by 3-4pm for commercial, and 'by the end of the day'  for residential. I had a meeting at work in the morning, but came home around 11:30am.
i figured that UPS wouldn't even get there until after noon. Sure enough, they were too efficient that day, and tried delivery at 9:15am. DOH! So I called UPS and scheduled to have it held at the local hub
for me to pickup. Unfortunately, the earliest I could pick up the laptop was going to be Thursday!!! Nooooo!!!!!!! :-) I went back to work. Damn. This has always been on of my complaints
about UPS. WHen I get packages via FedEx, I can pick the packages up the same night as the first delivery attempt.
</p>
<p>
When I got back to work, I decided to send nastygram to the customer service department of UPS about having to wait another day to pick up stuff at the local hub. I didn't really
expect a reply from them.
I've had very poor service and bad luck with UPS in the past. I've seen at least 3 servers with forklift holes in them upon delivery, and other packages
completely smashed and put in different packaging from what they left the manufacturers warehouse in. So of course, I've learn to expect the worst from UPS.Much to my surpruse, I received a reply from them in about an hour.
They apologized for the inconvenience and said that they've started a new On Hold Same Day Pickup service. Woohoo! Game on! I left my phone numbers with them, and they actually called me around
3:30pm telling me I could pick it up that night when the truck returned from it's round. Sweet! By 6:30pm, this little scream machine was in my awaiting paws.
</p>
<p>
Much to my surprise, the box was in mint condition. Expecting to receive a squished package, it was still in fact a square item! Bonus.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<a href="/blog/images/np5660/unopened_large.png"><img src="/blog/images/np5660/unopened_small.png" width="100" height="100" alt="Photo of Unopened Package" /></a>
	<br /><span class="caption">Click for larger image</span>
</p>
<p>
I noticed a warning type label on the top about the condition of the package when shipped, and that damage were the responsibility of the carrier.
I wish more shipper would put this on the packages.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<a href="/blog/images/np5660/notice_large.png"><img src="/blog/images/np5660/notice_small.png" width="100" height="100" alt="Photo of Package Notice" /></a>
	<br /><span class="caption">Click for larger image</span>
</p>
<p>
Once I cracked open the boxed, I found that they double boxed the shipment. ANother nice touch.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<a href="/blog/images/np5660/doublebox_large.png"><img src="/blog/images/np5660/doublebox_small.png" width="100" height="100" alt="Photo of Double Boxed Package" /></a>
	<br /><span class="caption">Click for larger image</span>
</p>
<p>
I like how the contents were packaged inside. Box of accessories on one side, and the carrying case on the other. The more protection the better.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<a href="/blog/images/np5660/theprize_large.png"><img src="/blog/images/np5660/theprize_small.png" width="100" height="100" alt="Photo of The Prize Inside" /></a>
	<br /><span class="caption">Click for larger image</span>
</p>
<p>
And just for completeness, the box o stuff; power brick, manual (Great manual!), Drivers disc, extra CD-ROM module, etc.
</p>
<p class="image">
	<a href="/blog/images/np5660/contents_large.png"><img src="/blog/images/np5660/contents_small.png" width="100" height="100" alt="Photo of Contents" /></a>
	<br /><span class="caption">Click for larger image</span>
</p>
<p>
Woohoo! We passed the UPS test. Onward.
</p>



<h4><a id="case">Case Design / Construction</a></h4>
<p>
On of the things I liked about her HP NP5440 notebook was that it had a beefy case design with nice sturdy material.
My Compaq was made of jello by comparison. This NP5660 has a nice sturdy case. The lid has just enough resistance and the hinge assembly seems to be nice
and rugged. Despite its 9.5 pound rating, I don't really find this laptop terribly heavy at all.
</p>

<h4><a id="setup">Setup / Installation</a></h4>
<p>
I had purchased a full copy of Windows XP Pro for my last laptop. Since it is now dead, I ordered the new Sager sans OS. I popped in the install CD and rebooted.
I went into the BIOS  before installation just for giggles. This machine has a full BIOS by all appearances, unlike some of those other laptops where you can add/change a BIOS password and change the clock and that's all.
After I installed XP and rebooted, the video was bumped up to 1600x1200 32bit color, although the XP driver was sluggish at best.
I popped in the drivers CD and installed all the drivers without a hitch. The user manual covers the installation of all the drivers for each OS. The manual refers to 98SE, ME, 200o, and XP, so I'll assume all those
other OSs are supported on this laptop. <acronym title="Your Mileage May Vary">YMMV</acronym>. The only hitch I had was with the USB 2.0 driver. If you double clicked the Setup.exe file, it ran but did nothing. IF you tried updating the driver via the device manager,
the driver installed and we were off to the races. Another reboot. Installed XP Service Pack 1 (thank god for DSL and 1.5 down speads) and all the latest hotfixes and security patches. One last reboot. No errors. No problems. All devices found, loaded, and operating.
</p>



<h4><a id="video">Display / Video</a></h4>
<p>
Initially, I set the display to 1600x1200 32bit. Very nice, although it will take some getting used to. I turned on ClearType and bumped the resolution down to a non-native size.
I tried both 1024x768 and 1200x1024. Under both resolutions, you could tell the screen text and such was 'different', but I wouldn't label it blurry and bothersome. All in all, I'm very impressed and happy with
the choice of UXGA. I actually think it looks a little better than the Sony laptop I tinkered with the same LCD specs.
</p>
<p>
Since I will be playing Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast, Unreal Tournament*, and Quake II on this thing, it was time to install 3DMark 2001. I installed 3dMark2001 Build 330. For the
tests, I left all driver settings and 3DMArk settings as is with the exception of changing the resolutions.
</p>

<ul>
<li>First run at 1024x768: 7100</li>
<li>Second run at 1600x1200: 3859</li>
<li>Third run at 1280x1024: 5148</li>
<li>Fourth run at 800x600: 8753</li>
</ul>

<p>
	All in all, this is a kick ass gaming machine for a laptop!
</p>



<h4><a id="performance">Performance</a></h4>
<p>
	Nothing to in depth here. A few SisSandra tests for the curious...
</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="/blog/images/np5660/sandra_cpu_math.png">CPU Math Benchmark</a></li>
<li><a href="/blog/images/np5660/sandra_cpu_mmedia.png">CPU MultiMedia Benchmark</a></li>
<li><a href="/blog/images/np5660/sandra_cpu_memband.png">MEmory Bandwidth Benchmark</a></li>
</ul>


<h4><a id="battery">Battery Life</a></h4>
<p>
	My first run at testing the battery life wasn't any surprise. It took just over 1 hour and 30 minutes to go from 100% charge to 3% charge, at which time
	the lappy started beeping and went into standyby mode.
</p>


<h4><a id="heat">Heat / Noise</a></h4>
<p>
The only noticeable heat comes out of the vents on the far left side of the laptop.
Not much heat on the top or on the bottom of the machine. The noise isn't nearly as loud as it could be. Slightly louder than a
regular laptop, but certainly nothing close to the noise coming out of a desktop box.
</p>


<h4><a id="conclusions">Conclusions</a></h4>
<p>
Overall I think this was a great purchase compared to what else is out there. Only time will tell when it comes to the durability of the machine.
My only gripe is that the hard drive clicks slightly more than my other laptops have in the past, but I'm sure I'll get used to it.
</p>

Hello, 

    Chris - I had written you about this laptop.  Just got mine.  Hit 7056 on 3DMark2001SE compared to around 5000 with my Inspiron 8200 2 GHz-M with a GeForce4 440 card. Happy with the purchase.  The *only* thing is the viewing angle.  The enhanced UXGA on the Dell is much wider, so if you're doing Photoshop work full-screen images look more evenly lit on the Dell.  *But* the Sager stays bright when you use battery power vs. AC.  The Dell tones down the screen on battery power to save juice.  

I've just installed all the software...time to play... :) 

PS - For anyone thinking of getting a larger hard drive: the Sager uses a 9.5mm 40GB Toshiba drive.  IBM's 5400RPM 60GB drive is 12.5mm, so it won't fit the Sager's 9.5mm hard drive chassis.  I believe you can get a Toshiba 60GB that will fit, but it will run at the slower 4200rpm.  In other words, if you want 5400rpm, the largest drive you can get for the Sager at the moment is 40GB. 

Just a bit of trivia for those wanting more space....

The keyboard is nice; similar to the Dell in feel, but not laid out exactly the same.  It's very springy.  The only thing I [personally] don't like about it is that the CTRL key is smaller than what you would find on the Dell. The Sager has a Fn (Function key) in addition to the CTRL key, whereas the Dell has one wide CTRL key in the same amount of space. 

So...if you're working in Photoshop, for example, or doing much copying-and-pasting, you have to be more precise on the Sager with your typing (or pinky) when using CTRL-V or CTRL-C.  I sometimes find myself hitting the "Fn" key when I want to be hitting the CTRL key. 

Pretty minor, but I thought I'd note it. 

Otherwise, a very nice keyboard.

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Scott
EMAIL: andrew77777@aol.com
IP: 64.94.173.111
URL: 
DATE: 11/18/2002 12:10:50 PM
Hello, 

I don't know how much Chris checks in here, so I'll give an answer. 

The laptop comes with a standard AC adapter that can be plugged into a wall. PowerNotebooks.com sells an auto inverter, but I'm going to guess it's the same as what you can get at Radio Shack. The only issue I've had with auto inverters is that I once had one that caused noise/feedback when I used it with my Dell laptop, but I don't know if this happens with other models. 

I have never timed it, but it usually takes a few hours to charge two onboard batteries from 50% (which is how much I normally use).  Using the 2nd modular bay for a spare battery should give you around 3 hours or so of use. In my personal experience, trying to charge the battery while using the laptop will result in longer charge times.  For example: I use the laptop for about an hour each morning on battery, then I plug it in when I get to work.  It takes most of the workday to bring two batteries back from 50% to 100% if the laptop is on and being used, but less time if the laptop is off. 

SCREEN:
This is truly personal preference. I don't like anything less than UXGA...although SXGA+ is decent.  The problem with UXGA is that font size is reduced, but the positive tradeoff is that you have a sharper screen. To deal with the decrease of the font size with the resolution increase, you can set your preferences in Windows and Explorer for larger fonts/larger icons.  You can also get a program called LiquidView from Portrait Displays which helps you quickly adjust your settings: 

<a href="http://us.portrait.com/products/lv.htm" rel="nofollow">http://us.portrait.com/products/lv.htm</a>

You should also activate Cleartype: 

<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/typography/cleartype/default.htm" rel="nofollow">http://www.microsoft.com/typography/cleartype/default.htm</a>

After doing those things, most text/resolution issues should be resolved.  Many application menus will still be small, but I [personally] have gotten used to it as a necessary evil to have the sharp screen.  

It's an ongoing conflict: 

higher resolution -> smaller type -> pixels less visible

lower resolution -> bigger type -> pixels more visible. 

I would strongly recommend previewing laptops at a local electronics store and comparing different native screen resolutions (XGA vs. SXGA vs. UXGA).

To bo honest, I have no idea. Neither the supplied USB2 drivers on the CD-ROM that came with the lappy nor the ones downloaded from the Sager site would install...they would just sit there in the background after being double clicked.

What I ended up doing was expanding the xp*.cab file in the USB2 directory, and choosing Update Drivers within the decive manager for the VIA USBController.

The other part of my problem appreared to be the drivers that came with the USB/Firewire enclosure itself. Eventually I ended up deinstalling all USB stuffs under device manager, uninstalling the USB enclosure driver from Add/Remove programs, and letting XP refind everything. After that, everything was happy again.

I love technology. I never had any problems with USB mice or USB memory card readers. It was probably a driver vs. mass storage device drver issues.

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Scott
EMAIL: andrew77777@aol.com
IP: 64.94.173.186
URL: 
DATE: 11/22/2002 12:49:29 PM
You haven't gotten an answer and probably won't get an answer. 

First, Sager, Alienware and Dell all have the official line that video cards are not upgradeable.  A Dell technician *might* tell you that you can upgrade the video card yourself, but in doing so, you violate your warranty.  The only place I've found that even carries the video cards by themselves is on eBay, and my last attempt to purchase one fell-through after a month of the seller having $250 of my money. It isossible you could get one from a technician though...when I tried to get one directly from Dell, I spent 7 hours on the phone. 

Since opening up most laptop cases violates the warranty and there are few online technical guides for doing so, very few people will be willing to do it to answer your question. Sorry!  I've spent a lot of time looking for the same answer.

Define 'clicky'?  The only clicky-ness I had was the 5400 RPM  hard drive. There is an IBM tweak utility that will let you change parameters of the IDE chipset. One of the options has something to do with buffering/caching. Set it to realtime, and the hard drive chattyness went away.

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: quiet1key
EMAIL: 
IP: 141.211.99.147
URL: http://www2.driverguide.com/cgi/download.cgi?uploads14/23187/VIA_USB2_Driver Package_V224.zip
DATE: 04/03/2003 08:45:02 PM
Regarding USB ports: To my knowledge, there are no reported hardware flaws in the USB ports installed on these systems; the problem is getting WinXP to recognize them as 2.0 ports instead of 1.1. The USB 2.0 drivers supplied by the manufacturers for the 5600Ds series of notebooks produced by Clevo Taiwan (also sold under the names Sager NP56xx, ProStar 5654/5600D, Alienware Area-51m in the U.S.) will not install correctly under WinXP. The reason is that the latest installer engine (v2.40) that comes with the driver bundle is buggy and, in my experience, will actually cease operation after unpacking the InstallShield data. I've seen only two working solutions for this up to now; one being what Chris had described earlier on: unpacking the XP drivers from the CAB archive and installing them manually. The second way is to find the driver bundle that comes with the previous version of the installer (v2.24 - see URL <a href="http://www2.driverguide.com/cgi/download.cgi?uploads14/23187/VIA_USB2_Driver" rel="nofollow">http://www2.driverguide.com/cgi/download.cgi?uploads14/23187/VIA_USB2_Driver</a> Package_V224.zip). The versions of the actual drivers in this bundle are not different than the newest one, only the installer is different so you'll still be getting the latest drivers. Worked just fine for my ProStar5654...
-----

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Anonymous Dame
EMAIL: 
IP: 68.5.252.49
URL: 
DATE: 06/16/2003 05:07:23 PM
from what i read in www.sagerforums.com, the main problem with sager notebooks is not the overheating, but rather 1) battery consumption and 2) lack of external battery supply. the amount of wattage this notebook eats is amazing. but if you're using it as a portable desktop, instead of a laptop, it should be fine. 

about overheating, it appears that some people have a problem with it, but these are isolated incidents caused by hardware defects. you shouldn't have any overheating problems. 

check out the distributer's policy on dead pixels. for poeple concerned with this problem, apparently most people don't have any dead pixel problems at all, just a few in a batch that get unlucky.

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: razzy
EMAIL: support@rpccomp.com
IP: 68.185.226.239
URL: 
DATE: 05/20/2004 03:33:48 AM
Ok, I just found this site by mistake trying to find some information about Linux on NP5600 series...I hope this might help somebody.
I bought my laptop from Mtech 2 years ago. I did some research before that and I reached the conclusion that Mtech, Prostar and Sager sell the same model, just the price is different. Before this one I had a Sager 3380 (if I remember well) which I know for sure that still works... and it was bought from Powernotebooks, many thanks to Donald!
Back to NP5600, it'a P4 2G, originally with 256 DDR, 20Gb, DVD, Floppy, 1400x1050 TFT. 
I have to mention that the notebook came from Prostar, confirming my thoughts about the manufacturers. I was pleased in the beginning, because the NP feels pretty sturdy. My happiness went away after about one month when I noticed some kind of flickering in the screen. I called Mtech customer service, and they told me to call Prostar, since they service both Prostar and Mtech.
After talking to somebody from Prostar, I decided to wait a little more to see what was happening. I watched the screen for almost a year and what bothered me the most was that sometimes when I was focused on something on the screen I could notice the flickering. It didn't happen all the time, just occasionally, and it was worse when I was moving the screen back and forth, but again, not all the time! 
As a computer technician I know that these kind of problems drive crazy everybody in the service!
In the meantime the latch broke, so I decided that it was time to call Prostar and send it there for repair. Another "little" thing was a label on the LCD, in the lower left corner, which was coming out more and more...
I have to mention that Prostar has a 72 hours repair policy. Well, on the website!
After the notebook got there I called Prostar again and talked to somebody, explaining him in detail what happens, when and what to look for. The guy seemed nice and we agreed to talk in 1-2 days. 
I called again in about 2 days and he told me that they couldn't notice anything wrong (that't how it always happens!) with the screen and that they need more time to figure out the problem. He also mentioned that they fixed the broken latch and removed the label from the screen. 
What could I say? "Ok, take your time and fix it!"
But here the nightmare starts. I call again in a few days, and talk to the same guy, and he starts asking me questions about what kind of flickering ,when, like he didn't understand what I told him probably three times before! The story is just halfway, and now it's very late, so I will continue tomorrow.

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: razzy
EMAIL: support@rpccomp.com
IP: 68.185.226.239
URL: 
DATE: 05/21/2004 04:18:01 AM
This is the second part of the article that I posted last night.
I forgot to write that before I sent the computer to Prostar I had upgraded the harddrive to a bigger one. It might not seem a big deal, but actually it was a reason for the flickering in their oppinion! First they didn't want to take a look on the laptop, then finally they decided to do it, warning me that "next time" I should have the original configuration.
Anyway, after another week, I found out that they upgraded the Bios to the latest version and apparently somebody noticed a problem which they say it was corrected by reinstalling the video driver. I tried again to tell the guy that the movement of the screen back and forth makes it worse, and I suggested that somebody might losen the hinges a little, as they can put some stress on the screen. He said: "No, they can't be losen, that's how it comes from the factory. If you want put some WD40 on them!" Great answer, isn't it? I payed $1800 to put WD40 on it! 
After 1 month I finally got the laptop back. It stayed in the service 3 weeks! It worked fine for a week and after that it started doing exactly the same. Even worse, I noticed that the LCD cover was broken in the lower left corner and the screen was moving inside. Besides, they forgot to put the screw that holds the harddrive in place! 
I called them again, and after about 30 min I found out that the warranty expired and they cannot do anything. Although I had extended warranty, it is not covered by Prostar, but by Philips-Magnavox. They mailed me the harddrive screw though. 
I was so furious after the conversation, that I open the laptop completely, till the last screw. I didn't care about voiding the warranty, anyway it didn't really exist! And I opened even the hinges, which were rusty inside (how they got rusty, who knows!?). I cleaned them and put some grease on to prevent them from further rusting. 
The plastic frame around the screen was broken in the lower left corner, and also the cover had a little metal washer that went out from the plastic enclosure, and that's why the screw didn't hold in that corner. So, after checking the prices ($35 only for the frame), I decided to fix it myself. I put some strong Epoxy and after 24 hours I removed the extra with a Dremel tool. 
Since then, no broken corner, no flickering (maybe just once in a while, after the computer comes on from standby, which is normal).
Conclusion: I still like this laptop, because it's very powerful. The harddrive and DVD are Toshiba. It's all in one (floppy, hard, CD), not like Dell either with floppy or CD. The screen is Hitachi, I checked it. So, even though it's not brand name, the components are good quality. I can't say the same about the case, which is not even close to Toshiba or Dell. I opened hundreds of Toshiba and Dell, and I can clearly see the diference in quality...But, if you need a low(er) cost, powerful laptop, I think it's a good choice. Remember to treat it gently. If you need an extra memory, call Apacer directly, they will be more than happy to sell you a 512 Mb for about 100-110, not 160-180 at Prostar. If something else breaks. you don't have too many options: either service (which hopefully will be a better experience), or if it's out of warranty, just to buy the spare part (from Prostar or whoever sells it, because it's proprietary) and to ask somebody to change it. BTW, I have to knock in a wood, it still runs Ok, and it went through hard work: video encodings, 3D design, never let me down. 
I hope this will help somebody. Thanks for reading!
-----

--------
AUTHOR: 
TITLE: The Router Flu
BASENAME: the-router-flu
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Hardware
CATEGORY: Hardware
DATE: 10/22/2002 06:14:19 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
Again, I must apologize to anyone trying to actually read this site over the last week. The router I received with my <acronym title="Digital Subscriber Line">DSL</acronym> connection (Efficient  5861) sucks monkey butt. It now sufferes from 3 problems.
</p>
<h4>Issue #1. No telnet after reboot.</h4>
<p>Every time I reboot the router, I can't telnet to it. The reason? The router keeps readding rules to deny telnet form the <acronym title="Local Area Network">LAN</acronym>.  Even after manually removing these rules and saveing the config. They are added again at the next reboot.
</p>
<h4>Issue #2. Ignoring filter rules.</h4>
<p>
In the kernel version SBC upgrade this router to, if will randomly ignore filtering rules. Once it ignores certain rules in the rule set, traffic then gets denies by the last rule (deny all). The effect is, <acronym title="Domain Name Service / World Wide Web">DNS/WWW</acronym> stops working for people trying to connect.
</p>
<h4>Issue #3. Missing filter rules.</h4>
<p>
I upgraded the kernel in the router. Now, instead of ignoring rules, is removes them altogether, causing the same problem for people trying to get to this site.
</p>
<p>
I'm working on getting a replacement this week. Bummer.
</p>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Sometimes you get the bear...
BASENAME: sometimes-you-get-the-bear
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: FreeBSD
CATEGORY: FreeBSD
CATEGORY: MicroShaft
DATE: 12/10/2002 10:13:47 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
...and sometimes the bear gets you.
</p>
<h4>Nugget of goodness #1: renewing a VeriSign <acronym title="Secure Sockets Layer">SSL</acronym> Certificate.</h4>

<p>
I've done this a million times at work without incident. So of course, this time MicroShat proves me a liar.
It was the usual routine, send in a new renewal request to VeriSign, pay for the renewal, and they send you back a 
nice shiiy, umm..shiny new certificate to install.
Upon opening the key manager in <acronym title="Internet Informaiton Server">IIS</acronym> and trying to install said certificate, you are greeted by a plethora of bad 
password errors even though you know and can use your passphrase on the verisign site.
To add flames to the fire, restoring the old keyset from backups also fails. Welcome to MicroShaft IIS SSL Keyring hell.
</p>
<p>
Luckily, VeriSign iwll let you replace the cert (revoke, resubmit new <acronym title="Certificate Signing Request">CSR</acronym>) for no charge within the first 30 days. I guess this happens a lot.
Once the renewal renewaled cert arrives, it installs fine. Weeeeeee.
</p>
<h4>Chapter #2: File server boot drive 'shits the bed'</h4>

<p>
As if I wasn't having enough fun. Come home, no proxy, no share drives, no tunes. Hmmmm.
Hookup ye olde monitor and keyboard. Oy boy Wally! Hard Read Errors! Reboot into single user; <kbd>$ fsck /. Hard Read Errors</kbd>!
Hot damn! It's a charlie foxtrot party!
</p>
<p>
Luckily, everything important is on raid, and the boot is only 4110MB @ &lt; %50 capicity. Reappropriate one spare 3200MB 
drive, reformat, repartition, reinstall minimal, mount elswhere, tar like crazy, rinse lather repeat.
All is well again; until I buy a new hard drive to repeat the process.
</p>
<p>
This is a great day.....FOR ME TO POOP ON!
</p>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: MT Custom Text Formatting Handlers
BASENAME: mt-custom-text-formatting-handlers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Perl
CATEGORY: Perl
DATE: 01/01/2003 02:43:22 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I can't wait to get my paws on <a href="http://www.sixapart.com/log/2002/12/simple_and_powe.shtml" title="MT post about custom text formatting plugins">this new MT feature</a>.As many others probably do, I've been struggling with formatting for quite a while.
</p>
<p>
My site is built and delivered using <acronym title="eXtensible Markup Language">XML</acronym> pipelines and stylesheets. The stock "Convert Line Breaks" isn't to friendly to <acronym title="eXtensible HyperText Markup Languag">XHTML</acronym>. It's easy to start having problems when you enter a single line containing &lt;ul&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; and the "Convert To Breaks" puts that inside of &lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt; tags, which is invalid XHTML markup.
</p>
<p>
The only way around stuff like that is to type in ALL of the XHTML into each post which is a lot of work. Plus having XHTML in post content makes content reuse a litle bit harder in place where text only content is desired. Writing your own text formatting handlers will solve this problem quite nicely allowing each situation to have it's own formatting routine.
</p>
<p>
Yes, I'm sure I could write a plugin, and use the <a href="http://www.bradchoate.com/past/mtmacros.php" title="Brad Choate's  MTMacros plugin page"><cite>MTMacros</cite></a> stuff from <a href="http://www.bradchoate.com/" title="Brad Choate's website"><cite>Brad Choat</cite></a>, but I just haven't yet. And like the article points out, I would still have to alter all of my templates with new/changed tags.
</p>
<p>
Assuming the new formatting selection box makes it into the code, I wonder how they'll deal with changing the format of all previous posts? Luckily, I've got a small amount of posts to tweak/clean/hack/bastardize when the time comes.
</p>
<p>
Bring it on!
</p>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: MT Upgrade / Changes
BASENAME: mt-upgradechanges
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Perl
CATEGORY: FreeBSD
CATEGORY: Perl
CATEGORY: Security
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 01/01/2003 12:15:06 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
	Day 1 of 365. Place your bets and sit down for the show. In no certain order I set forth the following degree of intents for the day:
</p>

<ul>
<li><strong>Upgrade <acronym title="Movable Type">MT</acronym> from 2.5 to 2.51 - Done.</strong></li>
<li><strong>Reapply / Recreate MT patches.</strong>
<p>There are two things that bug me about MT in my situation.</p>

	<ol>
		<li>
			<strong>Trackback URLs.</strong>
			<p>
				I rewrite the <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locators">URLs</acronym> on this site to avoid page/language specific file names, make them easy to remember, and
				make them more durable even if the page names change.
				See <a href="http://www.alistapart.com/stories/succeed/" title="Article about better use of URLs">"How to succeed with URLs"</a> and
				<a href="http://www.alistapart.com/stories/slashforward/" title="Article about better use of URLS">Slash Forward</a> over at
				<a href="http://www.alistapart.com/" title="Visit www.alistapart.com">A List Apart</a> for more info.
			</p>
			<p>
				So, <code>/blog/perl/</code> is really <code>/blog/perl.xsp</code>. While all of the links on my site use the
				<code>/blog/perl/</code> method, Trackback pings still send <code>/blog/perl.xsp</code> which means that if I ever change the file name
				, all external Trackbacked links will be broken while all the others will work. I know. I know. I can add another rewrite to remap
				<code>.xsp</code> to <code>.chl</code>. But I'd prefer to just have control over the Trackback URL format to begin with.
			</p>
			<p>
				So, it's time to get all proper and patch the admin interface to allow me to change the Trackback URL before it get's sent. Easier said than done.
			</p>
			<p>
				I think the least intrusive way to do this is to add hooks into the <code>$MTEntryLink$</code>  tag handler to call or use plugins.
			</p>
			<p>
				<strong>Ouch.</strong>. I just realized after all this time that my Trackback urls are completely bogus because an Entry's 
				Trackback Id <strong>IS NOT</strong> the same as the Entry Id. To make matters worse, there is no 
				<code>$MTEntryTrackbackID$</code> tag. The only way to get the Trackback ID is via the <code>$MTTrackbackURL$</code>, 
				which uses <code>$MTCGIPath$</code>. Even worse. If your CGIPath/Admin GUI is on a secure site, THAT is the url 
				used, not the url of the local site blog url. :-(
			</p>
		</li>

		<li>
			<strong>Outgoing HTTP Traffic</strong>
			<p>
				I love having MT send out pings to the "Recently Updated" list on the <a href="http://www.movabletype.org/">MovableType homepage</a>.
				I would also love to have MT send out pings to other sites in both Trackback and Updated form. However, this is where paranoia kicks in.
			</p>
			<p>
				I'm a big proponent of <a href="http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=Egress" title="Dictionary.com definition of Egress">Egress</a> filtering on the firewall/servers.
				In the unfortunate event that a server gets hacked or catches the viri of the week, the server will still not be allowed to initiate a
				connection to an external server on it's own; <b>especially</b> to common ports like port 80 to further spread the love. This cause a problem becuase
				MT Trackback/Updated pings need to be allowed out from the server to anywhere using port 80. Bummer.
			</p>
			<p>
				The solution? Well, in theory, the outgoing ping
				code using the <code>LWP</code> module could be told to bind itself to a different non-default ip/port on the server. The we can filter on the firewall/server to allow
				port 80 from this special address out to the internet port 80. This would allow pings out from MT, but all normal outgoing port 80 traffic on the machine to still be blockedd.
			</p>
			<p>
				We shall see.
			</p>
			<strong>Update</strong>
			<p>	
				Well, the good news is that I patched the docs and modules to add a new blog preference: <code>ping_interface</code>. 
				Now I can specifiy an alternate ip:port to bind to when sending out pings. Once I get my Trackback URLs fixed, 
				I'll work up some patches and submit them to the MT crew. Hey, why not right?
			</p>
		</li>
	</ol>

</li>
</ul>

<p>
If I get those two things done. I'll be happy.
</p>
-----

TITLE: New MT 2.51 Patches
BASENAME: new-mt-251-patches
STATUS: Publish

PRIMARY CATEGORY: Perl

BODY:
<p>
	Well, I may have not finished the list for today, but I made a big dent and fixed another problem as well.
	I've put together to following sets of <acronym title="Movable Type">MT</acronym> 2.51 patches that may never be of use to anyone but me.
</p>
<p>
<strong>MTEntryTrackbackID</strong> could easily be a plugin instead of patches, but I'm hoping that they might 
make it into the core MT program. If not, then a plugin it will become.
</p>
<h4>MTPingInterface</h4>
<p>
	<a href="http://today.icantfocus.com/downloads/MTPingInterface/2.51/" title="Download MTPingInterface patches">Download Files</a><br />
	As mentioned earlier, this set of patches allows me to specify what local ip or ip:port the server should
	bind to before sending out recently-updated or trackback pings.
</p>

<h4>MTEntryTrackbackID</h4>
<p>
	<a href="http://today.icantfocus.com/downloads/MTEntryTrackbackID/2.51/" title="Download MTEntryTrackbackID patches">Download Files</a><br />
	When circumstances decided that I needed to manually build my trackback urls, I quickly found out that
	the was no <code>&lt;$MTEntryTrackbackID$&gt;</code> tag to be found. There is now. :-)
</p>

<h4>Update</h4>
<p>
	Looks like the <code>&lt;$MTEntryTrackbackID$&gt;</code> code will make it's way into MT at some point 
	in the future. Although I realized today that I forgot to do the documentation patch for the new tag. 
	Doh! Should have that done shortly.
</p>
<p>
	Ben brought up a good point about the <strong>MTPingInterface</strong>: globalize it and put it in in 
	<code>mt.cfg</code>. Duh. Don't know why I missed that one. I'm also entertaining the idea of of adding 
	a setting in there to send pings through the proxy server as well.
</p>
<p>
	Ben also pointed out that there is an <code>AdminCGIPath</code> setting in <code>mt.cfg</code> that 
	appears to solve my problem. I missed it in the the CONFIGURAITON SETTINGS prtion of the docs. <acronym title="Read The Fucking Manual">RTFM</acronym>.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Eating Your Own Dog Food: Part 2
BASENAME: eating-your-own-dog-food-part-2
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Perl
CATEGORY: Perl
DATE: 01/03/2003 09:11:54 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
Well, I decided to eat my own dog food, and install the <a href="http://today.icantfocus.com/downloads/MTPingProxy/2.51/" title="Download link for MTPingProxy patches">
<strong>MTPingProxy</strong></a> patches on the live server. The install went without a hitch. 
Once I opened up the firewall however, only the first of all pings made it out the door. Easy fix for once.
</p>
<pre>
<samp>
@LWP::Protocol::http::EXTRA_SOCK_OPTS = 
   Addr  => $localaddr,
   Reuse => 1
);
</samp>
</pre>

<p>
The <code>Reuse => 1</code> part was the key. The <code>ip:port</code> socket from the first ping wasn't released for 
the second ping could bind to that same IP:PORT I suspect this is a scope issue with each 
<code>LWP::UserAgent</code>. This problem would've only effected people who used <code>PingInterface IP:PORT</code> 
instead of the recommnded <code>PingInterface IP</code>
</p>
<p>
Now it's time to fix my Trackback links. :-)
</p>

BODY:
<p>
I decided it was time to get a new more powerful UPS for the <a href="/blog/images/hardware/server_rack.jpg" title="Picture of my server rack">server rack</a> here in the office.
The currently has (3) 1U <acronym title="Pentium III">PIII</acronym> servers (<acronym title="World Wide Web">WWW</acronym>, <acronym title="Domain Name Service">DNS</acronym>, Firewall), (1) 4U dual PIII file server, and a small assortment of switches and nicknacks. So far, I went cheap on the UPS in the rack. It's a simple floor model <a href="http://www.conextproducts.com/ups/product.cfm?sku=CNB900" title="Conext 900AVR product details page">Conext 900AVR UPS</a>. Conext appears to be a rebranded APC UPS. It even came with APC PowerChute and APC labeled cables. OF course, it was nearly half the price of something comparable from APC. Go figure. But I digress.
</p>
<p>
So I've been to Best Buy more than a few times. I tend to buy stuff online since it's always cheaper than Best Buy, but shipping in this 1500AVR would probably suck butt, so I opted for the instant gratification. I've seen the <a href="http://www.cyberpowersystems.com/1500avr.htm" title="CyberPower 1500AVR UPS product detail page">CyperPower 1500AVR</a> in there a few times, but never felt the urge to purchase one those days I guess. Apparently today I was in the mood for a new toy.
</p>
<p>
Once installed, a review may be forthcoming.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Random Acts of Kindness
BASENAME: random-acts-of-kindness
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 01/04/2003 09:08:04 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
OK, I can't take it any more. I have to tell someone. :-)
</p>
<p>
For those who know me well enough, they will probably tell you that I'm a teddy bear pretending to be a hard-ass-bastard. A boy can dream can't he?
I'm is/was fortunate enough in this world to have wonderful parents who raised me and put me through college, a great <a href="http://margeauxsplace.com/" title="The girlfriends home page">girlfriend</a> [yes people, she <em>is</em> real] who can't keep her hands off of me, and a great job [aside from the usual bitching about work in general] that is fun and pays well.
</p>
<p>
Every now and then, I will just do something kind for a stranger for no reason. Call it stocking up on positive mojo. Sure, part of it is that it makes <i>me</i> feel good, but the way I figure it, that is a good kinda of selfishness.
</p>

<ol>
<li>
<strong>Snowed in at the Radisson</strong>
<p>
For Christmas, Margeaux and I went to my parents house on Christmas Eve and stayed until about noon. That's about an hour trip south of here. From there we drove up to her sisters house which is about an hour back plus another hour. It had already started to snow hard. By the time we were ready to come home that evening, the roads were a mess. It took us almost 2 hours on the turnpike to make it just a couple of exits. Clearly, it was time to get off the roads and snag a room somewhere. I always wanted to try Radisson, so we did. Check in, surf the TV to see what's available. High Speed internet access and I let <a href="http://66.72.53.129/blog/archives/entries/000039/" title="A review of my new Sager NP5660 laptop">my lappy</a> at home. So to the bar/restaurant downstairs we went. Dinner was great. Prime Rib Buffet. Yummy.
</p>
<p>
Total Bill:    ~$60.00
Total Tipage:     ~$40.00
</p>
<p>
Hey, it's just green paper with dead guys on it, and you can't take it with you. It was a slow night, so I'm sure the tip helped her out.
</p>
</li>

<li>
<strong>Lunch at Applebees</strong>
<p>
On any given weekend, we tend to hit the mall, grab some lunch, go to Borders or Best Buy or some such place. The weekend after Christmas we went to Applebees for lunch, and that urge stuck again. :-) We looked around for a bit and picked a family of 6; 4 kids, mom and dad having lunch together. Then we called our waitress over and sat her down, along with the waitress of the family we picked.
</p>
<p>
	<cite>"See that family of six over there?", "Yes", "Bring us there bill. Don't tell them it was us. Make something up."</cite>
</p>
<p>
Total Bill:    ~$55.00
Total Tipage:     ~$40.00 / 2 waitresses.
</p>
</li>

</ol>

<p>
But don't tell any one. If this should get out, it will ruin my image.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Comments Problem
BASENAME: comments-problem
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 01/04/2003 09:16:59 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I've broken something in my patching frenzy. When you click on comments under each post, you go to the comments form. The form posts correctly and the comment is stored, but the page tries to go somewhere else. I think this is related to my <code>CGIPath --> AdminCGIPath</code> change in <code>mt.cfg</code>. Sorry about that. Looking into it now.
</p>

<h4>Update</h4>
<p>
It is indeed because of my changes to <code>mt.cfg</code>. If I leave <code>CGIPath</code> set to the absolute admin gui url, all is fine. If I set <code>AdminCGIPath</code> to the full path of the admin gui, and set <code>CGIPath</code> to the relative patch to <code>/cgi-bin/</code>, the comment template chokes. Actually, it redirects to <code>/mt-comments.cgi</code> instead of <code>/cgi-bin/mt-comments.cgi</code>. I'm willing to bet this is an issue with the <code>CGIRelativeURL</code> handler in <code>lib/MT/Template/Context.pm</code>. We shall patch an see.
</p>
<p>
I'm sure I could just fix this by making <code>CGIPath</code> a full url incliding http://, but something feels wrong about hardcoding a domain name in there.
I think patching the handler to return the entire entry if it doesn't start with http/https is what the method is really after anyways.
</p>

<h4>Update Redux</h4>
<p>
It looks as if this problem is just a little more in depth than I first thought. Changing the <code>CGIRelativeURL</code> handler had no effect. Why?
Some things seem to use <code>CGPath</code> instead for no good reason that I know of. Awaiting an email response from Ben about how he would like to handle it, then I'll get to work.
</p>

<p>
I simply don't use Internet Exploder any more, esp. after Mozilla 1.0 went final. Why? Two very simple yet stunningly pleasing reasons.
</p>
<ol>
<li>
<strong>No virus of the week concerns</strong>
<p>
Don't get me wrong. If you own a PC, connect to the internet and <em>don't</em> have Norton AntiVirus or another like product installed, you should be taken out back and put out of our collective miseries. I'm so sick if seeing another MicroShaft Internet Information Server or Internet Explorer user trying to infect my machine in the logs. Come on. How long has Nimda and Code Red been out? Get with the fucking program people. I can surf using Mozilla, happily confident that there are much much less security issues with it.
</p>
</li>
<li>
<strong>Four Words: Middle-Click New Tab</strong>
<p>
Yeah, I know IE can use a 3rd party addin for tabbed browsing (See #1 above), but I simply can't function on the web without tabbed browsing in Mozilla.
Rock on Moz.
</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>
<em>Yes, I know I've been a post-o-holic lately. wBloggar really has changed my posting habits for a bit. It's sooo much easier than the <acronym title="Movable Type">MT</acronym> Admin GUI.</em>
</p>

STATUS: Publish

<p>
Day 5 of 365. Care to wager?
</p>

<ul>
<li>
<strong>Install new <acronym title="Uninterruptible Power Supply">UPS</acronym>. Done.</strong>
<p>
	This went pretty smooth. (4) servers, one PC w/ monitor, speakers, etc, and it's still only at half load. Not bad at all.
</p>
</li>

<li>
<strong>See <acronym title="Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers">LOTR: TTT</acronym>. Done.</strong>
<p>I swore to myself I wasn't interested, but I got roped into seeing <acronym title="Lord of the Rings: Fllowship of the Ring">LOTR: FOTR</acronym> last week.
I thought it was long and boring, but I just can leave myself hanging and miss the upcoming battle scenes.</p>
<p>
Wow was this movie long: 3 hours worth. We arrived at the theatre 5 minutes late and <em>still</em> managed to suffer though 6 more previews, then the Regal Cinemas "Welcome, Safety, Smoking, Enjoy" flick. On to the movie? Fuck no. ANOTHER fucking commercial before the movie. In the words of Monty Pythong "Get on with it!".
</p>
<p>
It was better than the first, but I still don't get what all the fuss is about. Guess I'm just a Star Wars fan at heart. At least Star Wars movies are complete movies with an end. The let's-split-this-movie-into-3-parts crap with an ending handing in the wind drives me crazy. It's like playing Beethoven's 5th and not playing the very last chord.
</p>
</li>
<li>
<strong>Server Administration via <acronym title="Universal Serial Bus">USB</acronym>/Serial Adapter</strong>
<p>I already have one server setup so I can administrate it via serial connection from the boot screen on in case I fubar something.
Another server has a modem on the serial port, and another will soon have the UPS on a serial port. I recently purchased this <a href="http://www.iogear.com/products/product.php?Item=GUC232A" title="GUC232A USB to Serial product information page">Serial to USB adapter</a> from <a href="http://www.iogear.com/">IOGear</a> and it works great in XP. It's also supposed to work under FreeBSD and the ucomm drivers, so I'll be tinkering with that this afternoon. It appears to be recognized fine by the kernel modules, not the trick will be to set it up so if works as soon as possible after the machine is turned on.</p>
</li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Netscape 4: Please Die Now.
BASENAME: netscape-4-please-die-now
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 01/05/2003 10:40:11 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
More surfing goodness. I found <a href="http://jogin.com/blog/archives/000183.php" title="Post about proper html markup">this post</a> over at <a href="http://jogin.com/blog/">jogin.com</a>. I feel our pain brother.
I've made it part of my mission at work to get our pages to be standards compliant. When a fair amount of your designers are GoLive users, this isn't such an easy task. Don't get me wrong. I think they are talanted people. But I also think it's time to cast off tools that don't make compliant code. It is also time to give Netscape 4 the big Fuck Off.
</p>
<p>
When I started this site, my main goal was to eat my own dog food. If my site wasn't standards compliant, at least in <acronym title="eXtensible HyperText Markup Language">XHTML</acronym>/<acronym title="Cascading Style Sheets">CSS</acronym> terms, then I couldn't quite convince people at work now could I? There still isn't a day that goes by that I hear the worst queston ever:
</p>

<blockquote>
	<p>"What about Netscape 4?"</p>
</blockquote>

<p>
Time to move on people. 
</p>
<blockquote>
	<p>
		"But the usage stats show a high percentage of Mozilla 4!. We can't piss off any customers."
	</p>
</blockquote>
<p>
No. The usage logs show assloads of Internet Explorer 5-6 browsers that still put <strong>"<em>Mozilla/4.0 (compatible</em>; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1)"</strong> as their user agent? What the hell is up with that shit still in 2003? As far as customers. Yeah, it sucks to piss off customers. But the logs don't lie. And as the Zeldman camp says, we need to develop for future compatibility, not past compatibility. Of course, Nutscrape for and the HTML hacks aren't even backwards compliant, so what's your point.
</p>
<p>
Don't even get me started on pixel-based layouts and spacer gifs.
Time for a 12 step program.
</p>
<p>
<cite>Hi. My name is $DeveloperName$ and I'm a Netscape 4-o-holic.</cite>
</p>
<p>
P.S. Love the site Tomas. Clean, appealing, and easy to use. Right on.
</p>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: The Real Fear Factor
BASENAME: the-real-fear-factor
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 01/05/2003 11:50:20 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
For the longest time, I've had this theory about people. A theory in which I know I suffer from, and I believe humans as a species also contend with. Fear is <strong><em>the only</em></strong>  real motivator in behaviour. Wha? Let me explain with a common everyday situation.
</p>
<p>
You're walking somewhere and see a homeless person? How many people look away, or cross the street? Why? Fear. Fear of feeling guilty? Maybe. It could be the fear of <em>feeling</em> something about the situation itself. Fear of letting the world inside because sometimes the world around us hurts our hearts no matter how much we tell ourselves it won't.
</p>
<p>
My girlfriend claims that I'm a good person, a "good soul" she says. Some <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000076/" title="Further examples of my behaviour">recent examples</a> may even prove it's somewhat true, but I still have the same problem. Fear. I am by my very nature and introverted personality. I spent many many years locking out the world because everytime I let it in I got hurt in some fashion. Such is life I think. While now a days I have more confidense and am generally happy about my position in life, fear still creaps in. Fear of guilt. Fear of hurt. Fear of no belonging. Some day I will overcome.
</p>
<p>
What do you think?
</p>
-----
