AUTHOR: 
TITLE: St. Murphys' Weekly Visit
BASENAME: st-murphys-weekly-visit
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WTF?
CATEGORY: WTF?
DATE: 05/27/2003 07:35:27 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
In an apparent effort to <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000197/#comments">not dissapoint Damelon</a>, I am today in what I could best describe as SQL Server / Hardware hell. Sit back children, and I shall spew forth a tale of woe and misery on this otherwise crappier Tuesday.
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
Note: I am a jack of all trades, webmaster of none. I know a lot about a lot of things programming, server, and admin related, but I am no means a full time DBA.
</p>
</blockquote>




-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
It all started simple enough. I wanted to import a 200MB text file into SQL, do some sanity checking on its contents, then put that data in another table. I had no more completed doing this on to similiar SQL2K servers when I moved forth to server #1 (aka, the bane of my existance). Upon runing the job to import the file, SQL Server spat upon me, and issued me error messages including this nugget of joy:
</p>

<p>
<samp>fcb::ZeroFile():  GetOverLappedResult()
Error: 1105, Severity: 17, State: 2
Could not allocate space for object 'TABLE_NAME' in database 'DB_NAME'
because the 'PRIMARY' filegroup is full.
</samp>
</p>

<p>
Oh dear. Now, taking this error at face value, the drive this database resides on has 53GB+ of free space. Even the database file itself has 600MB of free space inside of itself. :-( On top of that, every <kbd>DBCC CHECKDB</kbd> and <kbd>DBCC CHECKALLOC</kbd> I run comes up clean. And of course, <kbd>chkdsk</kbd> on all volumes during the reboot came up clear.
</p>
<p>
OK, I'll play your game. I open SQL Enterprise Manager, and right-click Properties of the afflicted server. Auto-grow is set to 10%. Not trusting that, I decide to manually increase the data file size for the <kbd>PRIMARY</kbd> filegroup. On I did so , and hit <strong>OK</strong>, the server was anything but.The file size increased in windows explorer, then immediately shrunk down to its original size <strong>minus</strong> and unused spacing. In english, that means the server had no room to write new rows. Errors everywhere. Grrrr. Of course, our newly found friend <samp>fcb::ZeroFile():  GetOverLappedResult()
</samp> has returned.
</p>
<p>
So, after moving all client to the old db server, I reboot this bastard machine. Once rebooted, and with <strong>no server load</strong>, it resisde the files the first time, without errors, and also ran the import job completely fine. <strong>#$%^@#%$</strong>. While I was adding flames to the fire, I also updated the raid controller firmware and drivers so I could rule that out. After some monitoring, I moved the clients back to this bastard SQl server.
</p>
<p>
Sure as shit, the import job now fails while the server is under load. Damnit. Now to make things easy, I'm now getting different errors:
</p>

<p><samp>
Time-out occurred while waiting for buffer latch type 3 for page (1:213424), database ID 5.
I/O error 2(The system cannot find the file specified.) detected during write at offset 0x0000004eeb0000 in file 'd:\MSSQL\Data\************.mdf'.
</samp></p>

<p>
Funny part is, the last error happens <strong>AFTER</strong> the server read, analyzed, and repaired the file it can't now seem to find. OK, now I have disk I/O issues AND a currupted database marked as <samp>SUSPECT</samp> in Enterprise Manager. Time to move clients back to the old SQL server and phone home to MickeySoft
</p>
<p>
I must say at this point, the MS support is one of the best supports I've ever used; even given the fct that I have to pay for it. After about two hours on the phone, we discovered that I couldn't even copy the file to another drive/controller. At least that time, the event log spit up some disk error messages. Support and myself decided to rebuild the file from scratch. No problem. The database itself is 1 of 3 nodes in merge replication, and it's not the master of the data in question.
</p>
<p>
Not wanting to leave well enough alone, I decided to shut off SQL, and run <kbd>chkdsk /F <em>/R</em></kbd>. The <samp>/R</samp> option is to recover bad sectors. Sure as shit, there was a bad sector smack dab in the middle of the data file. once checkdisk finished, I restarted SQL, the database recovered on we were on our mary way; again, still, more. Run the import job again. Runs fine. No errors. Move clients back to the new SQL server. Run import job. Job failes. Same errors. Database marked as suspect. More back sectors. Rinse, lather, repeat.
</p>
<p>
Well, at least now I have a pattern to follow and trouble shoot. Disk I/O shits itself under load. So, with that in mind, I copied all of the data drive to another controller/drive. Guess what? That's right, while copying those files to a seperate controller, <em>that</em> controller shit out a hard drive. Just to be clear. The raid5 volume on the controller with the volume that <strong>wasn't</strong> having problems blew out a hard drive. Now I had to find a spare, put that in the controller, and wait for it to resynce the raid5 volume. <strong>#$%^%$#</strong>
</p>
<p>Once that was done 50 minutes later, I totally removed the problemed logical drive within the raid controller config. As I sit here writing, I am still waiting on the recreated logical drive to syncronize in the hardware. After that, I still need to wait for the OS to low leve format the new volume. If that doesn't work, I will then participate in a killing spree at a location of my choosing using a weapon to be named at a later date.
</p>

<p>
Of course, all situations like these need peoms:
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
<cite>
Here I sit all broken hearted,<br />
tried to import, and barely started.<br />
I'll try again. It's not my fault<br />
All I see is fcb::ZeroFile():  GetOverLappedResult()
</cite>
</p>
</blockquote>

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Anonymous Coward
EMAIL: 
IP: 198.185.18.207
URL: 
DATE: 06/25/2003 01:57:42 PM
We were running into the infamous "timeout on buffer latch type 3" error and was caused by the autogrow in tempdb.  Apparently when SQL Server is getting hit pretty hard and tempdb is taking a timeout to auto-grow, SQL server shits its pants and times-out. This combined with the fact that tempdb shrinks down to its last set size after a restart, you'll hit this error pretty regularly after a SQL Server bounce.  (If tempdb auto-grow from a set 1GB to 10GB, after the restart tempdb will be 1GB again. - Just how gay is that?)

Anyway, we just manually set tempdb to a respectable level to resolve the problem.

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Day Two With St. Murphy
BASENAME: day-two-with-st-murphy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Hardware
CATEGORY: Hardware
DATE: 05/28/2003 11:30:19 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
Yesterday <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000199/">wasn't such a great day hardware/server wise</a>. Today, St. Murphy turned around, reminded me I'm not a DBA, and then gave me the finger.
</p>

<p>
Day 2. The server still chucks up sector errors during disk load while importing a text file. This is after completely destroying and recreating that drive volume at the BIOS and OS levels. On a whim, another searched IBMs website wasn't found the following article: <a href="http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=psg1MIGR-50419"><strong>ServeRAID - RAID-5 potential for data loss with ServeRAID under stress</strong></a>. Great! That sounds like our problem. Update the firmware. Update the drivers. The errors persist. Damn.
</p>
<p>
So, off we go, calling both Microsoft <em>and</em> IBM. Neither had any useful information or suggestions. Keep in mind, at this point, no one at Microsoft asked very few questions about the hardware or disk setup, nor did they suggest running <kbd>chkdsk</kbd> using the <kbd>/R</kbd> option to check for bad sectors.
</p>

<p>
After some thinking, and grasping for straws, we tried an experiment (one of many). Boot into the BIOS and turn off Hypertheading for the two XEON procs. Reboot with 2 CPUs instead of 4. Put server under load. Run the import job. Whola! No more disk errors. Then someone pointed out; if the CPUs are bottlenecked, the disks never get a chance to be bottlenecked. No shit! Obvious, but simple.
</p>
<p>
So, with that in mind, we enabled Hyperthreading again, added a new 15,000RPM Ultra320 disk, and moved the tempdb to another disk. Put load on server. Run import job. Errors are still gone!
</p>

<p>
So, it appears that our problem is with the disk configuration we chose for this server. For that matter, we have 2 other servers that never displayed this problem (with more restrictive disk configurations than this new one), reinforcing that theory that their older (only 2 instead of 4) CPUs never became less of a bottleneck to raise and disk I/O problems. Like I said, I'm not a DBA, just a programming/server jockey. Live and learn. I guarantee that we'll never make that mistake again.
</p>

<p>
The only thing that disturbs me is no matter what type of disk I/O load we have, no decept controller/driver/sql should ever spit out sector errors and corrupt the database.
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: CSS, Fixed Font Sizes and Dave Winer
BASENAME: css-fixed-font-sizes-and-dave-winer
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 05/29/2003 09:13:52 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I found <a href="http://scriptingnews.userland.com/2003/05/29#When:12:25:16AM">this snippet</a> over at Scripting News, which points to <a href="http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/200x/2003/05/28/CSS-IE">Tim Bray</a> and his opinions on fixed font sizes and CSS and IE.
</p>

<blockquote>
<p>
I've given Tim Bray his share of grief, but in this piece about the state of CSS, he nails it. <em>I esp like the bit about rocket science. Right on.</em>
</p>
</blockquote>

<p>
Also from Tim's page
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
So I determined to Do The Right Thing Dammit, and I have now invested several hours trying to figure out how to have nicely-resizeable fonts <em>and still have it look decent in at least the popular browsers</em>.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>
Personally, I don't see what the big deal is with using the font size keywords in CSS. Hell, this site uses them just fine. Sure, some browsers display things in different font sizes than I would like. Sure, sometimes this means some browsers get smaller fonts than we would like by default. But so what. Deal with it. Cope. Accept it. The web is dynamic, not static. It's about displaying and <strong>reusing</strong> information. Even if that small definition of reuse is a print vs. screen stylesheet.
</p>
<p>
Repeat after me 1000 times: <cite>The web medium is not a print publication.</cite>
</p>
<p>
While I am no one compred to Tim, or even Dave, I think they (Dave esp., and anyone else using CSS) needs to just let go of the baggage of trying to hold a death grasp on how different browsers display different fonts and font size keywords, hell, even positioning to and extend ("but in xxx browser it's 2 pixels off") . I also think using pixel sizes and font tags, irrespective of if it is more consistant across browsers, is more of a disservice to your web users and web standards as a whole since it doesn't promote reusability of your content.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: ASP.NET, Server Controls, and W3C Compliant Pages
BASENAME: aspnet-server-controls-and-w3c-compliant-pages
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: MicroShaft
CATEGORY: MicroShaft
DATE: 05/29/2003 06:42:53 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
Some <a href="http://www.haloscan.com/comments.php?user=scoble&amp;comment=3134">interesting comments</a> on the <a href="http://radio.weblogs.com/0001011/">Robert Scoble's</a> page regarding the previously mentioned <a href="http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/200x/2003/05/28/CSS-IE">Tim Bray article on MSIE and CSS issues and standards</a>.  Someone brought up ASP.NET server side controls, which prompted me to issue this rant.
</p>

<p>
ASP.NET server side controls are a fucking joke, from the standpoint of having W3C compliant HTML/XHTML web pages. Why a company who is on the W3C standards committees and was building a project like ASP.NET from scratch couldn't get their controls to output valid fucking HTML, let alone XHTML is beyond my fathom. Although, this same company can't seem to build a compliant web page on their site either so at least they're consistent.  Even if the XHTML specs weren't final, update the shit now that they are and give us something better.
</p>

<p>
This is even more maddening considering that server side controls in ASP.NET (along with the fact that ever page object is programmable without interspersed ASP code within the HTML) is the best idea to come out of .NET development. Things like the damn asp:form server side junk which outputs VIEWSTATE input elements even after you turn off all view state in the config is insane. So anyone who wants to move to ASP.NET and output W3C compliant pages (mainly XHTML) is forced into 3 shitty choices:
</p>
<ol>
<li>Don't use any server side controls. Yeah, lets have the programmers reinvent the wheel every page, and slow down development time instead of using postbacks.</li>
<li>Use server side controls and never have a page that validates.</li>
<li>Spend a retarded amount of time inheriting and overriding all server side controls using customized <samp>Render()</samp> methods to output the desired code.</li>
</ol>

<p>
Personally, #3 will be my option for another reason. I think server side controls that output HTML/XHTML is just a plain wrong idea from the start, esp. from the viewpoint of separation of content vs. look and feel.
To me, HTML4 is part of the look and view (View) of the site. What if you want text, or PDF, or XHTML? Then your screwed. All server side controls should output XML, and accept a pointer to a style sheet so you can transform it's output on the fly to whatever you need.  
</p>

<p>
Don't get me wrong. I love ASP.NET and C#, even after admitting that I'm a big Perl/Apache fan and usually hate the dark side. I'll never use .NET for freelance websites or projects so people don't have to buy SQL or W2K Server and licenses. But I'm not happy about having to jump through many hoops to be efficient using existing server side controls AND trying, begging, forcing ASP.NET to output compliant pages. 
</p>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Email Disclaimers, Lawyers, and Irony
BASENAME: email-disclaimers-lawyers-and-irony
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Humor
CATEGORY: Humor
DATE: 06/04/2003 07:21:07 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
While the details must remain slim, I have witnessed something that, as a Sys Admin,  angers me, and makes me cry with laughter at the same time. We've all probably seen emails from people who have a 12 mile paragraph of legal-mumbo-jumbo-confidental-private-such-and-such-law disclaimers at the end?
I hate those. It's stupid, unenforceable, a waste ob bandwidth, and just plain bad netiquete, esp when you're on things email lists that get archived.
</p>
<p>
Well, I know someone who's place of daily entertainment decided to append such a disclaimer to the end of every outgoing email, <em>at the advice of their legal council</em> of course. Needless to say. those types of disclaimers only serve to point out how paranoid or ignorant a place really is IMHO.
</p>
<p>
Well, sure enough, the irony kicks in. Weeks later, that <em>same</em> legal coucil sends a confidental email with attached confidential document to an incorrect email address that gets routed to a bunch of regular joes instead of the indended higher up recipient. To top that off, the aformentioned legal council <strong><em>had no legal confidental disclaimer</em></strong> at the bottom of their emails, as they tell other people to do. Forget the whole fact that if the email is so damn confidental, encrypt the fucking emails!
</p>
<p>
Fitting I think.
</p>

Are you really trying to imply lawyers should be sensible or display practical intelligence or *gasp* not abuse the resources of others?

The truth according to me is that lawyers don't actually want anything ever really, truly, secure. They want things actionable so they can litigate, but they don't actually want them secure. STATUS: Publish

BODY:
<p>
I present to thee: <a href="http://www.zug.com/pranks/credit/">The Credit Card Prank</a>.
</p>
<p>
Quite the example of a futile security effort. I always thought that signing your card was stupid. If someone stole your card, or created their own, the signature on their receipt and on the card will match likely anyways since they either created a new card, or just rubbed of te current sig.
</p>
<p>
I find this even more funny since <strong>a)</strong> my signature is pretty much jibberish (since I can't really write in cursive any more. I print everything and I'm a lefty), and <strong>b)</strong> when we asked my college prof to sign some school forms, he would ask us "What name should I use?". "Abe Lincoln!". Mr Lincoln and Mr. Einstein signed many of my college forms for me. :-)
</p>
<p>
Props to <a href="http://www.keithdevens.com/weblog/">Keith Devens .com</a> for the link.
</p>

--------
AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Web Development: IE Sucks
BASENAME: web-development-ie-sucks
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 06/07/2003 10:10:29 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I found this link via <a href="http://www.scripting.com/">Scripting News</a> to <a href="http://blogs.osafoundation.org/mitch/000224.html">this post by Mitch Kapor</a> about his switching to Mozilla.
</p>
<p>
All other security, browsing, and standards issues aside between IE and Mozilla based browsers, I find that as a web developer, I simply can't develop web pages using IE any more. It's to devoid of decent page information. In Mozilla-based browsers, a page info command yields me dates, time, size, forms, images, cache info, standards info, etc. With browser extensions, I can even see the full resquest/response headers, turn off stylesheets, turn off font tags, highlight tables and block elements, show form contents, and even convert form post's to get's. 
</p>
<p>
All of that makes my life as a web developer a whole lot easier than using IE. I would switch for those reasons alone, let alone less security issues, and more standards support.
</p>

CONVERT BREAKS: 0

BODY:
<p>
It's pretty rare that I'm on the receiving end of good customer service. It seems that more and more we all get the shaft, and people forget how to treat a customer like a customer instead of a burden.
</p>
<p>
Last weekend we ordered 2 pizzas and an order of cheese sticks from the local Papa Johns for delivery. When the guy arrived, they were missing one pizza. He left the one pizza and cheese sticks, without getting paid, and headed back to Papa Johns.
</p>
<p>
About 20 minutes later, the driver returned. However, instead of our missing pizzia, he returned with and entirely new order: 2 additional pizzas and another order of cheese sticks which we paid for. The first pizza and cheese stick were free. Fantastic.
</p>

This is a 1st come 1st served business and if the customers before you take alot of time then yours will be later as a result.Answer the door(DON'T scream "Who the f*** is it?"--you called us!!) when we get there don't make us ring and knock repeatedly before you answer because you're busy on the phone or whatever and PLEASE have the common courtesy to set the phone down while we are conducting business,you're going to need both hands to take the pizza/wings/sodas and exchange money.And if you simply MUST run to the store/take shower,etc leave the money to pay with someone that is available<br />
If you find it necessary to send your children to the door,make sure they are big enough to carry the HOT pizzas with out mishap,and if you want to tip,tell them how much<br />

WE ARE going to check your id--just like any other place you shop, so don't leave a check with your child or the babysitter,etc The same goes for Credit/Debit cards.YOU have to be there to show ID to prove you are who you say you are,for your own safety as well as for our own----if your checks or credit card were stolen, you'd expect us to catch that by checking ID,so don't yell and curse at us for asking for it.(and please return the pen I loaned you to write your check because you couldn't find one in your own house)<br />
The faster I can finish our transaction,the faster I can deliver the next order.Remember that the next time you wonder what took us so long and don't add to the problem.Time is money in this business and we try our best to make our deliveries as fast as possible in order to make a decent living,so don't "gum up the works"by <br />
taking more time than necessary to complete your order/delivery<br />
When we tell you your order will be delivered in 45min-1 hr,listen to ALL we say,don't call back in 30-45 min wanting to know where your pizza is,you're wasting the time needed to take orders/make pizzas,etc and its not going to get it there any faster by<br />
causing us to stop what we are doing to answer your irate phone call,plus you are tying up needed phone lines We KNOW you don't like to be on hold so think about the other customers you are causing to be kept on hold while we spend more  unecessary time on you<br />
Just so you know,Screaming,cursing and threatening us<br />
will not get your order there any faster either--   I admit we are not perfect,although we really do try our best, we do make mistakes,and if you have a LEGITIMATE complaint we will do all we can to rectify it,but there is no reason to call us every vulgarity you can think of,(you know we can't respond in kind so we make a good target when you have had a bad day,but would you like us to treat you that way at your workplace?)<br />
Don't accuse US of being rude when we are NOT,simply <br />
because you can't get your way and have free pizzas<br />
when its not late or made incorrectly.There are many scam artist out there and they use this as the excuse whenever they can't get their food free any other way.<br />

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Damn You Computer@!#$%
BASENAME: damn-you-computer
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WTF?
CATEGORY: WTF?
DATE: 06/12/2003 09:58:14 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
For something based on 1's and 0's, computers really suck serious monkey nut sometimes.
</p>
<p>
So I put together my new game machine, and everything appears to work fine. Boots on the first try w/o error after assembly. Memtest86 runs overnight without issue. 3DMark01/03 run looped without issue. XP Pro install goes fine.
All in all, and easy time.
</p>
<p>
But at some point, the mouse starts going herky jerky (yes, that's a technical term) on me. I searched Google, and found everything from IRQ conflicts, to drivers; bad MS Hotfixes to AGP port speed; disk contention to CPU issues. You name it. I tried it. 
I even tried 3 different mice. Nothing helped.
</p>
<p>
Then the light bulb went on. Mouse X/Y movement jittered, but the buttons, scroll wheel, and the keyboard all worked fine. Hmmm. Then I remembered that all 3 of the mice I tried were some sort of optical mice. So I dug up an old crusty ball mouse (he he, he said ball) and sure as shit...it worked!
</p>
<p>
Now, that solution by itself would make sense to me if it weren't work the fact that I have been using that very [problemed] optical mouse on my old computer, on the same OS, using the same drivers, <strong>on the same desk surface</strong> without any issues. WTF? I then plugged the problem mouse back in. The jitters reappeared. I put a sheet of white paper underneath and the jitters went away? <em>Again, What The Hell?</em>
</p>
<p>
Why these optical mice worked on my old system on this desk surface, yet those same mice jittered on my new computer on the same desk is a mystery to me beyond fathom.
</p>

<p>
No wonder Worldcom/MCI had money problems, <strong>because their fucking billing system doesn't work!</strong>
That's right, they can't bill or do math do save their life. Sit back, and I shall share a story of billing lunacy.
</p>
<p>
A long itme ago, in a land far far away, I was responsible for some servers on a Worldcom Dial Office ISDN line. This conneciton was a 'business' class account with half a C class of IP addresses and 24/7 uptme with <strong>no</strong>, I repeat <strong>no/none/zip/zilch/nada/zero</strong> hourly connect charges.
</p>
<p>
Lo and behold one month, a new bill arrives for <strong>$5000.00+</strong>!@#$# And get this, I was being charged for a months worth of hourly charges, which is wrong. To top that off, it was for <strong>3368.368 hours</strong> for <strong>30</strong> days of service. Now let's go over that again: 24 hours x ~30 days somehow equals 3368.368 hours. Sure it does, on their planet. Our normal bill for the first 7 months or so was ~$126.00 including tax hoopla.
</p>
<p>
So, I call in to billing and customer service. After 2 days, no one knows what the hell is wrong. They claim they will issue a credit and to pay the normal bill. Next month, you guessed if, same shit. I call  in again. Everyone pleads ignorance, says thers nothing thay can do, and they again issue a credit for the mysterious hourly rates on an unlimited account and we pay the normal fee.
</p>
<p>
This shit went on for 6 months before we terminated our account with them. To this very day, we are still getting bills and phone calls about collection. Calling customer services and billing <em>still</em> yields pure ignorance and a blind eye to an obviously horribly stupid billing system. #$%$#@#
</p>

<p>
It's nice to see I'm not the only one that gets irked by .NET server controls and W3C standards. 
<a href="http://www.splorp.com/blog/archive/2003_06_01_archive.html#105604957243094752">This Slurp post</a> about sums it up. 
I <a href="http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/archives/entries/000204/">mentioned this problem before</a> as have many others in the <a href="http://www.asp.net/Forums/ShowPost.aspx?tabindex=1&amp;PostID=34126">ASP.NET forums</a>. 
Even Mr. Zeldman has <a href="http://www.asp.net/Forums/ShowPost.aspx?tabindex=1&amp;PostID=34126">picked up the thread</a>.
<ins>The <a href="http://www.yayhooray.com/thread/25122.html">YaHooray thread</a> on the issue as well from Zeldman.</ins>
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>
The frustrating part of this whole exercise is that .NET does generate some of the controls as seemingly compliant XML-ish code. But it's certainly not consistent and there is no obvious way of controlling any aspect of the tag or attribute formatting. This isn't exactly what I was hoping to hear, but I'm not giving up quite yet. If there's a way around these limitations and constraints, I'll find it.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>
I wrote Grant and email, and he <a href="http://www.splorp.com/blog/archive/2003_06_01_archive.html#105616763534105021">posted it</a> to his site. Someone <em>does</em> read my emails! :-)
</p>
<p>
For all the work that went into .NET, and ASP.NET, it's a shame that they took the shitty way out on this one.
Hell, considering the point of ASP.NET was to seperate code from presentation, why in the hell do they have code serve up HTML?
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Firebird: Import SSL Certificates?
BASENAME: firebird-import-ssl-certificates
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Security
CATEGORY: Security
DATE: 06/22/2003 11:36:41 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
While I really like the <a href="http://www.mozilla.org/projects/firebird/">Firebird 0.6 browser</a>, there is one annoying thing that is keeping it from being my only browser: the apparent lack of SSL certificate options or management; forcing me to still load Mozilla on occasion..
</p>
<p>
When I installed my latest servers last year, I decided to protect things like IMAP, POP3, SquirrelMail and the MovableType admin pages with SSL using custom signed SSL certificates. In IE and Mozilla, this meant loading a client side certificate to gain access to those services. I haven't yet found a way to do that in Firebird, which means it can't access my MT and webmail pages. :-(
</p>

Then someone brfoke that encryption too. Then came more legal threats and shutdowns. Now, the Xbox gets owned again, this time by their <a href="http://lists.netsys.com/pipermail/full-disclosure/2003-July/010895.html">own buffer overflow</a>. I know, that's a shocker. <p>

"The protection of our intellectual properties and copyrights, and those of our partners, is a top priority and therefore we reserve the right to pursue and take action against anyone facilitating piracy of videogames".
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>

Shouldn't I be able to run non-game stuff on my hardware if I so choose? An exploit doesn't promote piracy, software piraters do.
</p>
<p>

<i>"Shouldn't I be able to make backup copies of my discs and play them?"</i><br /><br />I'm not 100% sure about what the law says in the US, but AFAIK, no, you can't. You can make backups of <i>data</i> not <i>programs</i>. It is illegal to make a copy of a program for personal use, while it is perfectly legal to do the same of a CD or DVD. Unless of course the US law deviates from the "standard".

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Customer != Criminal
BASENAME: customer-=-criminal
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WTF?
CATEGORY: Games
CATEGORY: WTF?
DATE: 07/08/2003 09:14:06 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
&lt;rant&gt;
</p>

<p>
Ok, repeat after me: <strong>the customer is not a criminal</strong>. Something small that pisses me off to no end: CD Copy Protection.
</p>
<p>
When I spend $40+ dollars for a game, I damn well should be able to make a backup of that game and stick it in safe place, or better yet, use the copy and leave the original alone. I'm so sick of being treated like a criminal after spending some hard earned green on some computer entertainment.
</p>
<p>
I try to be a responsible computer user. As such, having an offsite backup of important data is a given.
Everytime I purchase a new piece of software, it get's backed up and stuffed in my drawer at work all safe and sound from any mishaps at home. Yet these game companies seem to think I'm a criminal and put fscking copy protection on their CDs.
</p>
<p>
What mystifies me further is that some games like Splinter Cell have it, and other games like Jedi Knight II don't. Not only that, but it's ass easy get altered .EXE files that don't look for the CDs when starting the game. There are also a few programs out there that can zap these fuckored weak ass sectors and produce a working normal CD. So why do they bother? The hardcore pirates already use the more complicated methods to pirate their warez, and the only ones punished are Joe Six Pack Home User.
</p>

<p>
Back when I purchased Civ3 by Infrogrames/Firaxis, it couldn't be copied. I sent them a nastygram letting them know how unhappy I was that I couldn't even make a backup copy. Their response was pretty much to the effect that "You aren't allowed to make backups, read the EULA". Hey, fuck you. According to most legal cases here in the US, esp. ones about unbundling software and reselling the parts says it all: if it acts like a sale, then it's a sale, and what the customer does with it afterwords (shy of duplicating and selling copie) is fair use like reselling a book. My copy. Bite my ass. I shall crack all your CD protections to protect my investment and there isn't jack nut you can do about it.
</p>

<p>
&lt;/rant&gt;
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Programmer vs. Musician
BASENAME: programmer-vs-musician
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 07/10/2003 07:44:57 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
As my two reader may already know, I graduated college with a B.A. in Music Education K-12, and a B.S. Music Performance: Percussion. At one point, I even had a real teaching certificate for the State of Ohio.
Given all of that, my first job was as a web programmer at an ad agency in Cleveland. Go figure. But every time I think about it, it makes sense (to me).
</p>
<p>
For me, they both hold some of the same qualities. I get to learn new things all the time. I get to memorize things like crazy. I get to create things from scratch. What really turned me on to programming was that it felt like a success from the standpoint that I, a musician, could program, and learn programming without going to all those stuffy college classes. :-)
</p>
<p>
Not to mention the fact that after 5.5 years of college @ 20-23 credit hours a semester, I really didn't want anything to do with teaching music.
Part of that is the fact that I don't think kids today can get the two things they need in school without it becoming a supreme court case: 1) their ass beat, and 2) hugs and understanding.
</p>
<p>
As time goes on, I realize that for my personality, programming is simply a better choice. In college, is was the type of musician that could memorize a piece of music in no time flat, but I was a great music reader [realtime], and improvising wasn't to hot for me. When it came to improvising I couldn't let go of the details. Everything had to work in my head, which is a great thing in programming.
</p>
<p>
I'm sure I'm not the only one. It seems to be that a lot of computer type people were/are musicians. Must be that right-brain/left-brain thing. Of course, I'm a lefty, and we're the only people in our right minds. :-)
</p>

<p>

</p>
<p>

</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Search Foo
BASENAME: search-foo
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 07/15/2003 08:10:13 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
More random acts of tinkering. I need some opinions on this one. On the 404 error page, I decided to add a search form pre-populated with the path of the requested but missing file. Currently, it strips off any trailing slashes and file extensions, splits each part of the path into a single word, then puts those words into the keywords field.
</p>
<p>
In English, that means that any searches for <samp>/new/stuff</samp>, <samp>/new/stuff.htm</samp>, <samp>/new/stuff/</samp>, etc. gets put into the keywords fields as <samp>new stuff</samp>.
</p>
<p>
Nothin fancy there really. My question is this. Do you think it's better to present people with a 404 page letting them know that something is missing and filling out a search form for them, or is it better to simply redirect the user to the search results automatically?
</p>
<p>
Some of that comes down to user expectations. Which is less confusing? Being told something isn't found, or asking for one page/url, and ending up at a search page for no particular reason?
</p>
-----

TITLE: TopStyle Pro 3

STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0

ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW

BODY:
<p>
Lately I've been in the mood to do more CSS. I've tried HomeSite in the past, and even earlier versions of <a href="http://www.bradsoft.com/topstyle/">TopStyle</a>. I've never been a fan of WYSIWYG editors, even IDEs like Visual Studio/Interdev that try and second guess me. I'm a diehard Notepad/Textpad user. Give me a text editor or give me death, and leave my formatting alone!
</p>

<p>
On a whim I decided to try TopStyle Pro after I had tried <a href="http://www.bradsoft.com/feeddemon/">FeedDemon</a>, a new RSS newsreader developed by the same BradSoft via Nick Bradbury.
</p>

<p>
After a day of tinkering, I bought a copy. Nick has a real gift and making highly usable GUI programs that Do What I Mean and get out of the way. That's a hard skill to come by, even for Microsoft sometimes.
</p>

<p>
What I like even more, is the non-greedy licensing. I buy 1 license for me to use this program anywhere I am; at home, at work; on the laptop, on the desktop.
That's how it should be. That makes me want to pay for software. This draconian per per user, per seat, per connection crap the BigCO's play is for the birds.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: BC/MIT Refuse RIAA Subpoenas
BASENAME: bcmit-refuse-riaa-subpoenas
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WTF?
CATEGORY: WTF?
DATE: 07/22/2003 07:36:23 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I've said it before, and I'll say it again. The RIAA is getting out of hand.
Apparently MIT and Boston College are <a href="http://www.boston.com/dailyglobe2/203/nation/BC_MIT_decline_to_name_students_in_music_use_case+.shtml">refusing some RIAA subpoenas</a>. Good for them. Now for the disturbing part. Read the next paragraph carefully:
</p>

<blockquote>
<p>
In a subpoena addressed to MIT, the association is demanding the name, address, and phone number of a student who used the nickname ''crazyface''<strong><em> to download at least five songs</em></strong>, including Radiohead's ''Idioteque'' and Dave Matthews Band's ''Ants Marching.''
</p>
</blockquote>

<p>
Now read that excerpt again. A student is going to be sued for <strong>downloading</strong> songs from Kazaa, not for sharing songs with others.  I would pay a heavy some of money to be there in the court if this student had proof of purchase of these songs/CDs before he/she downloaded them.
</p>
<p>
If I had bigger balz and time to spare, I would sit around Kazaa for weeks on end downloading nothing but MP3s of songs on CDs I already own. Fsck the RIAA.
</p>
<p>
Who's to say I don't own what  I'm downloading? Maybe my CD is borked and I need to download a track that is scratched? As always, the <a href="http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=03/07/22/2221223">Slashdot thread</a> is interesting.
</p>

<p>
Try this question on for size. I posted it to Slashdot.
</p>
<p>
What's the difference between:
</p>
<ul>
<li>I own a CD</li>
<li>I put the CD in my CD player</li>
<li>Someone else accesses that CD via Cat5 cable (assuming only 1 person at a time can dowload/listen)</li>
</ul>
<p>
and
</p>
<ul>
<li>I own a CD</li>
<li>I put the CD in my CD player</li>
<li>Someone else accesses that CD via 1/8" headphone cable</li>
</ul>
<p>
They're both sharing. Will the RIAA come hunt me down because everyone I work with can listen to my CDs using headphones? Will they also hunt down the person using the headphones?
</p>

You think that's bad?  Here is the text of a message I sent to Register.com late last year.  Things may be better there now, I don't know.

"We are now into the 13th day of getting jerked around.  I again request access to the account I paid for.  I have made repeated requests by e-mail and by phone call.  The e-mails have been ignored, the phone calls have not been at all helpful and have been counterproductive. 

Let me reiterate & summarize.  I registered 4 domain names in bulk with register.com.  A single charge of $140 was made tomy credit card.  These were all renewals of accounts with register.com.  For some reason 3 of the registered domain names were transferred to an entity whose legal name and business structure is unknown. One of the 4 domain names was retained by register.com.  This transfer was made without notice or request.

My host server changed IP addresses for its accounts.  I had to change the IP addresses for each of the domain names with the registrar so that the domain name would again point to physical location of the web server.

I accomplished this in a few minutes in my account atregister.com without human intervention for the domain name not transferred to Global Partnereu (GPN).  I changed it in a few minutes with human assistance at Network Solutions after I ironed out a stale e-mail address problem.  In 2 weeks I still have been unable to get access to my account at register.com's cut rate no frills entity.  I would caution anyone to be careful and avoid the same problems I faced in trying to get a very simple problem solved.  I started this process 2 weeks ago and I am no further ahead today than I was back then.

One of the problems with the storefront entity, partnereu, is that it has little technical phone support.  There is a webpage where you can send an e-mail, and there is a phone number with a recorded message that states that there is no telephone technical support.  It is strictly e-mail support.

My first e-mail requested access to my newly created partnereu account.  I stated that the register. com password did not work.  It was answered in a few days and it suggested I get access to the stale e-mail account on file.  They could send a new password to that e-mail address.  I answered it immediately asking if I could use a quick method of getting access similar to that used at register.com and network solutions.  I stressed the urgency of getting the account up& running. This e-mail was ultimately answered 1 week later.

In the meantime I sent e-mails everyday telling them the urgency of getting my business back on-line.  It was very frustrating being ignored for a very simple problem and not being able to talk to a human.  In retrospect, the whole problem could have been solved by merely unlocking the account so that it reset to the default register.com password.  It was a 2 minute solution.

After several e-mails, I became frustrated and calledregister.com to have them help me out since they unilaterally transferred my account to their unresponsive no frills entity.  Register.com offered absolutely no help and gave me the impression that because I registered the domain names with their affiliate I was on my own to resolve it.

My e-mails to register.com had an auto-reply to contact the partnereu e-mail support group.  I reiterated my dilemma a few times by e-mail copying both register & its affiliate telling them they both had responsibility for getting me access to the account so I could get my business up again. The response was always auto-reply from register pointing me to partnereu and dead silence from partnereu.

After several days of no response from partnereu and no access by phone, I tried to pressure register.com telephone support staff to help.  I tried to convince them that I had originally registered with them after responding to their request for renewal of the domain names.  They told me that the renewals were not technically with register but were sent by Global Partner Network (GPN)/register.com

I told them that I originally registered the domain names onthe register.com website and had renewed annually with register.com  They told me that this time GPN sent the renewal e-mails and I had really renewed with them.  I told them that I had an e-mail receipt from register.com.  Despite my paid receipt from register.com with no reference on it to any other entity, I was advised that internally it was a transaction with GPN/partnereu.  They were unwilling to give any assistance.

Each time I tried to call register.com I was transferred to the partnereu voice mail line stating that there was no technical support.  Several times I said to the register.com support staff, "no don't transfer me to the voice mail again".  They would put me on hold for a few minutes and say,"Ok I am going to transfer you to a human this time.  I always got transferred to the voice mail brushoff.

One of the register.com support staff tried to convince that my real problem was with Logika.  They had technically acted as the registrar and they would be in the best position toresolve this.  Even though I knew that Logika did not have my account, I called them.  They told me that they were not involved in the least.  They acted as a front end in the process not interfacing with the consumer.  The support guy there told me to look at whois.com where it clearly stated that the registrar was register.com.

After I waited on hold at register.com support line several times over the next few days, I heard the advertisement suggesting callers easily transfer their existing domain names to register.com.  I had one of my few original ideas. I said to the support guy that I had 3-4 domain names in an account with another registrar.  I wanted to know if I could transfer one of them to register.com.  After an enthusiastic 'yes' I gave him the name of my transferred partnereu domain name.  I figured it was worth another $35 to get my businessup & running.  When i told him the domain name, he said it was already registered at register.com.  Despite it being at entity partnereu I could not transfer it back.  It was locked.

On one call to register.com I found a helpful lady who fetched a helpful GPN support guy instead of the usual transfer to limbo or expression of sympathy at my having registered with another registrar.  After verifying my identity the staff person emailed me a password & username to access the partnereu account.  The password did not work. The staff person declined to give me his name & phone number because he was temporarily helping the GPN staff & probably couldn't be reached again.  

I sent an immediate e-mail and called partnereu billing inquiry line.  I told them I had just spoken to a person who sent me a bad password.  I asked to speak to him so I could get another one.  Unfortunately, partnereu does not have 24/7help like register.com so I had to wait until the next day. I asked the billing person to please put a written note on the guy's desk to reset the account & e-mail me a newpassword.  The next day I got the same password a second timeand it did not work either.  The average wait time on all myphone calls was 15 minutes; the longest was 35 minutes.

I received a phone call on Friday from a register.com employee who said he was a supervisor.  I called back & let it ring 10 times without getting any voice mail.  I called Saturday, this time I was able to leave a phone message.  I checked to see if maybe this guy would be helpful and have e-mailed me a password, or reset my account so it would be up &  running for the weekend.  No such luck.

I sit here on my 13th day of great customer support waiting for the 2 minutes of assistance I need to get my business up & running.  I have spent over 10 hours during this time just trying to get access to the account that was transferred for me."

I am having my accounts transfered to another registrar for 1/2 of the cost this year.

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Ogg Vorbis / WMP9
BASENAME: ogg-vorbiswmp9
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Music
CATEGORY: Music
DATE: 07/29/2003 11:50:15 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
So, why do we hate Windows Media Player 9 again? I'm not sure anymore.
</p>
<p>
I'm all for the daily MicroShaft bashing. At one point in the past, I got sick of Windows Media Player, and decided to rip and convert my CDs to Ogg Vorbis. Even with a fast machine, and a fast CD drives, this takes time.
</p>
<p>
I recently did a reinstall on my new computer, and just did a restore of my old one; which also included the WMP9 upgrade on both. The ease of use from a "Copy From CD" standpoint, especially when you can just pop in a couple of CDs, let it rip them, then swap in a couple more,  seems a lot quicker than using CDEX and some of the other "open" formats and rippers.
</p>

<p>
Maybe it was the DRM crap? Or was the substandard MP3 quailty crap? Who knows. I can rip .WMA files with the copy protection turned off, and play them on my other Windblows boxes. So what's the downside again?
</p>

<p>
Maybe it's just faster ripping to WMA because it has better hooks into Direct*, and my Audigy2 card drivers. Either way. I think I might start [and finally finish] ripping my CDs to WMA format and be done with it.
</p>

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Arcterex
EMAIL: arcterex@ufies.org
IP: 216.232.119.73
URL: http://arcterex.net/blog
DATE: 08/06/2003 03:07:38 PM
Interesting.  Under linux I run a program (well, actually a shell script) called 'abcde' (A Better CD Encoder) which takes a couple of args (-N -x IIRC) that simply auto-rips a cd to ogg and ejects the CD.  Re-insert new cd, hit uparrow+enter and repeat.  Or GRIP which will auto-rip on CD insertion and eject, so all you do is pop in CD after CD and close the drive when it pops out.

And it will do it into whatever format I want, ogg, mp3, wav, flaac, etc.  No DRM, no propriatory crap.

Maybe the quality of rippers under windows sucks badly compared to a shell script. Sad, but hey, as a monopoly MS can give you anything they want right?  Choice doesn't matter. 

Oh, and I think the reasons to hate WMP9 includes that whole "privacy" thing, and the propriatory nature of it all :)

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: About The Author
BASENAME: about-the-author
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: __default__
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Static

BODY:
<h2>Who's on first?</h2>

What's on second. Third base. I don't give a darn.

<h3><a id="who">Who?</a></h3>

Just the fax ma'm:

<ul>
	<li>my bills come addressed to Christopher H. Laco</li>
	<li>30ish years of age and counting</li>
	<li>there's no place more exciting than Akron, Ohio</li>
	<li>at work, they claim I am the Jack of all trades, Webmaster of none</li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="what">What?</a></h3>

This sites construction is a huge departure from where I was a year ago. Not to mention that it probably is way more complicated than it has to be for 90% of it's content, but that is on purpose. :-)

Stop back later. I plan up creating a section under <a href="/projects/">Projects</a> that goes into great detail of how I built this site.

<h3><a id="when">When?</a></h3>

While you are reading this, I am furiously not working on this site. That's what the trained shaved monkeys are for.

<h3><a id="where">Where?</a></h3>

Good ole' Tallmadge, Ohio.  Yes, that's right. The excitement capital of northeast Ohio. NOT.

<h3><a id="why">Why?</a></h3>

This site is my attempt to get back into the website creation groove.

It's been far too long since I've had a personal website, and I need to scratch that itch. Plus, I have way to many opinions about various topics to keep under wraps any more. I've spent the last year or so maintaining existing websites @work and @home, and now it's time to get back on the wagon.

The other reasons I built this website:

<ol>
	<li>Because I can damnit, because I can!</li>
	<li>Force myself to get my new <a title="Toyz!!!!" href="/about/servers/">servers</a> operational.</li>
	<li>Get converted away from Windblows web development</li>
	<li>Learn more <a href="http://www.freebsd.org/">FreeBSD</a> stuffs</li>
	<li>The monkeys made me do it!@#$%</li>
	<li>Learn more <a href="http://www.perlmonks.com/">Perl</a> stuffs</li>
	<li>To much free time on my hands</li>
	<li>Learn more <a href="http://www.axkit.org/">AxKit</a> stuffs</li>
	<li>Taunt others from afar</li>
	<li>Learn more <a href="http://httpd.apache.org/">Apache</a>stuffs</li>
	<li>And get converted away from Windblows webdevelopment!</li>
</ol>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: He's Dead Jim
BASENAME: hes-dead-jim
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 08/04/2003 09:04:54 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I decided that the web server having write access to things was bad, so I've turned on suExec for my blog. This means all files are rebuilt as me. This also means that when comments are posted, the index page and the entry page will NOT reflect the comments immediately. A fare trade-off I think.
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Damelon Kimbrough
EMAIL: dkjournal@divagation.com
IP: 62.212.118.137
URL: http://divagation.com/journal/
DATE: 08/05/2003 05:36:07 AM
Okay Chris, what do you know that I don't? Yeah, yeah, lots of things, I'm sure, but comments not being posted immediately because of security? Is this something others using MT should be concerned about or...?
-----

COMMENT:
AUTHOR: Chris
EMAIL: chrislaco@hotmail.com
IP: 208.44.49.7
URL: http://today.icantfocus.com/blog/
DATE: 08/05/2003 09:51:36 AM
Well, it's all situational really. You can run the MT CGIs one of two ways: as the Apache user/group (www), or as a specifi or logged on user. If you run MT under the www account, Apache needs write access to generate your web files when you add a post, and when someone adds a comment. I'm no to fond of that.

So I decided to run the CGIs under my account via suExec. While this means all new entries write files as me and Apache doesn't need write access, it also means comments no longer work because Apache doesn't have write access.

I installed a set of patches from Sean Willson (http://www.seanwillson.com/archives/2003/04/27/000501/) that allowed me to turn off index rebuilds when comments are posted. I also hacked the MT::App::Comments and MT::App::Trackback modules to not rebuild entries when comment are posted.

I then installed mt-rebuild (http://mt-plugins.org/archives/mini/mtrebuild.php) and set up my crontab to schedule rebuilds of the index page and entries to display any new comments.

-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Help Using This Site

<h2>It's the help, stupid!</h2>

<h3>Accessibility</h3>
	
This site has been constructed with the goal of being as usable as possible by those users with physical, mental, technological or other disabilities using varying types of readers or browsers. Should you have any problems, questions, or concerns about this site's functionality, please feel free to contact me at <a href="mailto:chrislaco@hotmail.com">chrislaco@hotmail.com</a>.

<h3>Standards Compliance</h3>

Great effort has been made to ensure that every page on this website validate as <acronym title="Extensible HyperText Markup Language">XHTML</acronym> 1.1 <a title="View XHTML Strict specification" href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11/">Strict</a> and that the style of this website uses valid <acronym title="Cascading Stylesheets">CSS</acronym> syntax. In an effort to keep this author "eating his own dog food", please send an email to <a href="chrislaco@hotmail.com">chrislaco@hotmail.com</a> if you find any page that does not validate. Please make sure to include the <strong>full </strong> <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym> of the offending page. Public floggings may be necessary.

<h3>Navigation Enhancements</h3>

Extra navigational aids have been added to this site to make it easier to use.

<h4>Navigational Link Tags</h4>

Extra links tags have been added to each page to better describe the relationship between pages and make navigation quicker in certain browsers. Most pages include "Top", "First", "Previous", "Next", and "Last" relational links where possible. The should be viewable in text based browsers like Lynx. Graphical browsers like iCab and Mozilla have a special toolbar that will read these links and present the appropriate buttons. Mozilla users can enable this toolbar by selecting <kbd>View menu, Show/Hide, Site Navigation Bar, Show Only As Needed</kbd>.

All pages also have "Help", "Copyright" and "Authors" links defined as well as the bookmarks "Return to Top" and "Jump to Content" which will always take you to the top of the current page and to the start of each page's main content respectively. Individual entry archive pages also have "Jump to Comments" and "Jump to Trackbacks" defined, which will take to you the comments and trackback sections respectively.

<h4>Keyboard Shortcuts (Access Keys)</h4>

This website makes use of keyboard shortcuts or "access keys" to make moving from item to item of section to section quicker for those who use the keyboard more than the mouse. On windows, these can be used by pressing <kbd>ALT +</kbd> the access key. On Macs you can use them by pressing <kbd>Control +</kbd> the access key.

The following access keys have been defined for use on every page of this site:

<dl>
	<dt>Access Key 1</dt>
		<dd>Home Page</dd>
	<dt>Access Key 5</dt>
		<dd>Jump to Content/Skip Navigation</dd>
	<dt>Access Key 6</dt>
		<dd>Return to Top</dd>
	<dt>Access Key 9</dt>
		<dd>Help and Accessibility Statement (this page)</dd>
	<dt>Access Key V</dt>
		<dd>Validate Current Page</dd>
</dl>

Access keys are also defined for each element in the forms used on this website. The access key for each form element will be underlined within the name or label for that element. For example, the access key for the field labeled <strong><span class="underline">N</span>ame</strong> would be <strong>N</strong>. Pressing <kbd>ALT+N</kbd> on Windows or <kbd>Control+N</kbd> on a Macintosh should bring focus to or place the cursor in the <strong>Name</strong> field.

<h3>Layout and Design</h3>

This site's "look and feel" is applied using <acronym title="Cascading Style Sheets">CSS</acronym>. The default style sheet for this website uses relative font sizes so each user may increase or decrease the sizes of all the fonts used using the option in their browser. If your browser doesn't support cascading style sheets, this site should still be fully functional and easily readable.

If you would like to select a different cascading style sheet ("skin") of specify on of your own for this website check out the <a href="/preferences/">site preferences page</a>.

<p>
While I think XP is a good improvement over Win2K and NT4, they all suffer from one (maybe two) really annoying 'features'.
</p>
<p>Whenever I have a mapped drive to a network share, or My Documents mapped to a network share, or network share history in the address toobar of IE....erm..I mean Windows Exploder, and the network or that network share becomes unavailable, the OS comes to a screeching halt.
</p>
<p>
Pulling down the address bar in IE takes minutes to time out before showing me internet addresses. Using windows explorer to navigate other shares and folder takes a minute to time out. Basically, a 'modern'  'multi-tasking' OS delays everything under the sun just because a network share goes away for a few minutes. Damn annoying.
</p>

<p>
Of course, the problem is magnified by the fact that windows eplorer is IE, and that fact that it is set to a single instance and thread. Sure, I can TweakUI it so each windows explorer instance is a new thread, but I shouldn't have to.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Large Cycles
BASENAME: large-cycles
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 08/07/2003 11:16:17 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I've been thinking a lot lately about work, my enjoyment and distaste for it, and the seemingly large cycle that my work and home computing habits go through.
</p>
<p>
When I started my curent job 5 and a half years ago, I didn't know 1/4356th of what I know now. Some of my first projects were big ones that meant I spent weeks and months coding the same project. Back then there was just myself and one other doing programing and pages. After programing all day on the same project, I'd come home and do the same at home for another 5-6 hours. I was a true code monkey.
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
Over the years, I've had more meeting, more people, more projects, and the fun has left the building with Elvis somewhat. It seems the day to day modis operandi is to get projects done quickly instead of correctly. And as a programmer, correctly means the RIght Way using the propery tools and methods. We have so many options at our disposal; .NET, Web Services, Security Roles, XML Schemas; yet we never use them to their potential  because of time. I never get to code 8 hours straight for weeks on end because of the project of the week.
</p>
<p>
Don't get me wrong. I couldn't work with better people, and our group gets along like no other I've ever seen. I just can't seem to catch my learning/programming groove like I used to. Hell, I learned all the Unix junk at home just to keep myself amused. I've even got a website to convert from ASP to Unix that could keep me busy, but I can't seem to get into it.
</p>

<p>
Music was the same way. After about 5.5 years of music in college, I jumped ship to computers. Maybe it's time to jump top a new topic again.
</p>
-----

--------
AUTHOR: 
TITLE: I Know I Shouldn't
BASENAME: i-know-i-shouldnt
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 08/09/2003 11:59:54 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I'm working on a not so new project at home. The goal is to use an existing RDBMS in an OODBMS way. I know, it's a project doomed to failure, but that won't stop me from trying. :-)
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
Essentially, I need to convert an old ASP driven site to something MySQL/Perl/XML driven. It's just your average run of the mill commerce site. But here's the kicker. Rather than just move the database from MSSQL to MySQL, I wan to revamp the schema completely.
</p>
<p>
If you've ever tinkered under the hood of MS Commerce Server, one of the things that stands out is how it stores part/product information. Rather than trying to make all parts fit into the same mold, part are grouped by type, and each type has it's own set of attributes. A CD and a wrench are the same, so why shove them into the same mold?
</p>
<p>
In a nutshell, you have tables thatg store the part definitions and other tables that store the part attributes. Instead of a part geing a single row with its attributes being the columns, each row is a different attribute name/value for a given part.
</p>
<p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Worms Worms Everywhere
BASENAME: worms-worms-everywhere
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WTF?
CATEGORY: WTF?
DATE: 08/20/2003 08:02:54 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
And not a drop to eat. First, the details. This latest round of email worms is just plain nasty. I woke up this morning to 120+ emails (marked correctly as spam by SpamAssassin) that are from infected machines on the net being sent to an old webmaster account that hasn't been used on the web in years. Not only that, but I've also received about 30+ MAILER-DAEMON responses to emails sent out by infected machines using that same webmaster emails address as the From: address.
</p>
<p>
Yes, I've checked the headers to make sure none of them actually came from my IP block. Thanks Postfix!.
</p>
<p>
So let me proclaim and jump on the bandwagon: <strong>SMTP Email Is Dead</strong>. Any internet protocol that can be brought to it's knees by simply falsifying the From: header simply needs to be shot dead and put to rest.
</p>
<p>
Time to go disable that old account now.
</p>

--------
AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Running Perl Scripts Within Eclipse
BASENAME: running-perl-scripts-within-eclipse
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Perl
CATEGORY: Perl
DATE: 08/21/2003 10:36:52 PM
-----
BODY:
<p><em>
Since I've had to tinker myself to death twice to figure this out, trying every variation under the sun to avoid various path, @INC and working directory issues, I might as well post it here so I can find it again later after the next OS reinstall. :-)
</em></p>

<p>
<strong>
It appears that sometime around 3.0 M6 to M8, Eclipse changes the way it interacts with the Working Directory. What used to work, now doesn't. It appears now that I have to make the Working Directory ${project_loc} to get things to wkr as they should. Anyone got any more info on the changes?
</strong>
</p>


-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<h2><a id="introduction">Introduction</a></h2>
<p>
If you're running the <strong><a href="http://www.eclipse.org/">Eclipse IDE</a></strong> and <strong><a href="http://e-p-i-c.sourceforge.net/">EPIC</a></strong>, the perl editing plugin for Eclipse, at some point you are going to want to run a script you're writing. At that point, you have two options: <strong>a)</strong> run it in a seperate command window, constantly switching back and forth between that and the IDE , or  <strong>b)</strong> try and convince Eclipse to run it behind the scenes and display the results in the <strong>Console</strong> view.
</p>
<p>
I'm lazy, so I chose the latter of the two. :-)
</p>
<p>
Unfortunately, setting up the <strong>External Tools</strong> configuration to run my scripts within the IDE turned out to be harder than it should have been.
I'm sure part of that was due to <acronym title="I-D-10-T error between the chair and keyboard.">Pilot Error(TM)</acronym>. After some RTFMing and a quick scan of the Windows Command  Shell, I stumbled upon the solution below.
</p>

<h2><a id="setupsteps">Get On With It!</a></h2>

<ol>
	<li>
		<p>
			First, open the <strong>External Tools</strong> configuration window (<strong><a href="#figure2">Figure 2</a></strong>)  by
			choosing <strong>Run -> External Tools -> External Tools...</strong> from the menubar as
			shown in <strong><a href="#figure1">Figure 1</a></strong> below.
		</p>
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure1.png" id="figure1">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure1-thumb.png" alt="Figure 1: Opening External Tools configuration window" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 1:</strong> Opening External Tools configuration window
		</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p>
			Next, highlight the <strong>Program</strong> entry in the <strong>Configurations</strong> box on the left (<strong><a href="#figure2">Figure 2</a></strong>) and click <strong>New</strong> button below
			to create a new configuration as shown in <strong><a href="#figure3">Figure 3</a></strong>.
		</p>
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure2.png" id="figure2">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure2-thumb.png" alt="Figure 2: External Tools configuration window" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 1:</strong> External Tools configuration window
		</p>
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure3.png" id="figure3">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure3-thumb.png" alt="Figure 3: Creating a new configuration" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 3:</strong> Creating a new configuration
		</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p>
			In the <strong>Name</strong> field. type in the display name for this configuration. We're going to be creating a simple configuration to run Perl with warnings enable, so enter <kbd>perl -w</kbd>
		</p>
		<p>
			In the <strong>Location</strong> field, we will point Eclipse to use the command shell.
			By using the command shell instead of the perl executable, we can change directories and run anything we need to prior to actually
			running the perl script in question. The location of <kbd>cmd.exe</kbd> will vary depending on which MS OS you're using.
			I'm running XP Pro, so I entered <kbd>C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe</kbd>.
		</p>
		<p>
			In the <strong>Working Directory</strong> box, I pointed it to <kbd>C:\WINDOWS\system32</kbd>, the same location as <kbd>cmd.exe</kbd>.
			There is probably no reason to do so, but what the hell. It can't hurt right?
		</p>
		<p>
			Now for the magic. In the <strong>Arguments</strong> box I entered the following
		</p>
		<p style="text-align:left;">
			<kbd>/C "cd ${container_loc} &amp;&amp; perl -w ${resource_name}"</kbd>
		</p>
		<p>
			What is all that junk anyhow? Here's a breakdown.
		</p>
		<dl>
			<dt><strong>[cmd.exe] /C</strong></dt>
			<dd>Carries out the command specified by string and then terminates</dd>

			<dt><strong>cd ${container_loc}</strong></dt>
			<dd>Change directory to the directory containing the currently selected perl script in the IDE</dd>

			<dt><strong>perl -w ${resource_name}</strong></dt>
			<dd>Run the selected perl script using perl.exe with warnings turned on</dd>
		</dl>


<p><em>
<strong>Note:</strong> I used <kbd>perl</kbd> instead of <kbd>wperl</kbd> because I'm running the 1.4.x runtime. If I use <kbd>wperl</kbd> instead, I actually get the quick DOS popup window even though <kbd>wperl</kbd> is modeless , <strong>Run in background</strong> is checked, and the 1.4.x runtime supposedly fixed this issue (<a href="http://e-p-i-c.sourceforge.net/faq.html#A_DOS_box_flashes_on_the_screen_can_it">EPIC FAQ Entry</a>). I suspect the opposite would happen if I were using the 1.3.x runtime.</em></p>

		<p>
			After entering the data above, click <strong>Apply</strong>. You should end up with something looking like <strong><a href="#figure4">Figure 4</a></strong>.
		</p>
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure4.png" id="figure4">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure4-thumb.png" alt="Figure 4: Enter configuration values" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 4:</strong> Enter Main configuration values
		</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p>
			Next, click on the <strong>Common</strong> tab in the configuration you just created and click the <strong>External Tools</strong> checkbox in
			the <strong>Display in favorites menu</strong> (<strong><a href="#figure5">Figure 5</a></strong>) settings group
			and click <strong>Apply</strong>. Then hit <strong>OK</strong> to close the External Tools window.
		</p>
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure5.png" id="figure5">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure5-thumb.png" alt="Figure 5: Add configuration to External Tools menu" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 5:</strong> Add configuration to External Tools menu
		</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p>
			If all goes well, your new external tool configuration should be listed in the <strong>Run -> External Tools</strong> as shown in <strong><a href="#figure6">Figure 6</a></strong>. If not, then don't kill the messenger. :-)
		</p>
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure6.png" id="figure6">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure6-thumb.png" alt="Figure 6: New configuration in Run -> External Tools menu" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 6:</strong> New configuration in Run -> External Tools menu
		</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		Highlight a perl script of your choosing in the <strong>Navigator</strong> view and pick your configuration from the <strong>Run -> External Tools</strong> menu.
		If all goes well, the results of your Perl script should now appear in the <strong>Console</strong> view similiar to <strong><a href="#figure7">Figure 7</a></strong>.
		<p class="image">
			<a href="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure7.png" id="figure7">
				<img src="/blog/images/perl/eclipse-runperl-figure7-thumb.png" alt="Figure 7: Perl script outputs into Console view" />
			</a>
			<br />
			<strong>Figure 7:</strong> Perl script outputs into Console view
		</p>
	</li>
</ol>


<p>
There, that wasn't to so bad. If you're feeling creative you can create additional configurations for running <kbd>make</kbd>, <kbd>make test</kbd> and <kbd>make clean</kbd> on CPAN-like packages created using <a href="http://search.cpan.org/search?query=ExtUtils%3A%3AMakeMaker&amp;mode=module">ExtUtils::MakeMaker</a>.
</p>

True, it is easier, but I've had problems in the past (at least on Windows) where the current working directory and @INC is based on where you're running perl from, and not where the script itself resides due to using the full script path. Plus, (and maybe I need to create an extended example), using cmd.exe instead allows me to prepend additional commands that perform make clean and make before I run the actual Perl script in question.

$|=1;        # make STDOUT unbuffered

for( my $i=0; $i

/c cd /D ${container_loc} &amp;&amp; perl -w ${resource_name}

You can specify arguments by including one of the Eclipse-supplied variables on your command line.  If you use "${string_prompt}", Eclipse will pop up a dialog when you Run; "${file_prompt}" will pop up a file selection box.  You can enter multiple arguments in one string_prompt...

Unfortunately, 3.0M7 is a bit stoopid, and right after the argument dialog pops up, it pops up a small yellow banner-ish thing at the bottom of the main eclipse window, which submerges the argument dialog under the window (so you have to alt-tab back to it).  Annoying, but minor.

COMMENT:

URL: 
DATE: 02/26/2005 01:21:28 AM
Another tip for Linux / BSD / Solaris / OS X:

Some users may have problems seeing output from certain scripts.  To fix it, you must redirect the output to stdout, like so:

-w ${resource_loc} &>1

Note the "&>1".  This should go in the arguments section.

With a little Postfix magic, two can play this game.
</p>


<pre>
<samp>/etc/postfix/main.cf
     smtp_sasl_auth_enable = yes
     smtp_sasl_password_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/saslpass
     smtp_sasl_security_options =
 
/etc/postfix/transport
     .rr.com     smtp:[smtp.sbcglobal.yahoo.com]
 
/etc/postfix/saslpass
     smtp-sbc-v1.mail.vip.sc5.yahoo.com     xxxx@sbcglobal.net:yourpassword
 
$ postmap /etc/postfix/transport
$ postmap /etc/postfix/saslpass
$ postfix reload</samp>
</pre>


<p>
There. Now I can sit around without stressing over undeliverables and see how long it takes fro the DNS request to go through the SBC pipeline.
</p>
</ins>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: MSSQL Roles Somewhat Worthless
BASENAME: mssql-roles-somewhat-worthless
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: MicroShaft
CATEGORY: MicroShaft
DATE: 08/25/2003 06:42:47 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
Roles. Internal SQL Groups. A way to abstract the who-can-do-what kind of details. Sounds good right? Not exactly.
</p>
<p>
I had one simple mission this morning: create a set of roles in MSSQL and write a stored procedure to return a list of user rights based on which roles they're in. Once the roles were written, and user accounts and domain groups were added to those roles, it looked like a simple matter of running <kbd>IS_MEMBER(<em>'role name'</em>)</kbd> in T-SQL and creating a resultset.
</p>
<p>
Much to my dismay, try as I might, I couldn't get this to work for my current login using NTLM. As it turns out, the <kbd>IS_MEMBER()</kbd> function does absolutely <strong>nothing</strong> when the current login is a member of the System Administrators role #$#@*!  Just because someone is an admin in the local server <strong>doesn't mean they should be all poweful in the dataase all of the time</strong>. At least have the damn function return accurate results.
</p>
<p>
From better to worse it seems. The only way to remove myself from the SysAdmin role is to remove myself from the Domain Admins group on that server, whi9ch means I can't administer that server, and logging into the server as a generic server admin account is even worse since it doesn't allow us to know who did what when everyone administrates with the same generic account. Damnit! That make roles just about worthless in my book.
</p>
-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Of Semantics, Structure, And Syntax
BASENAME: of-semantics-structure-and-syntax
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: WWW
CATEGORY: WWW
DATE: 08/28/2003 06:04:16 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
An <a href="http://simon.incutio.com/archive/2003/08/28/structuralVsSemantic">interesting trail</a> found over at <a href="http://simon.incutio.com/">Simon Wilson's site</a> and leading back to <a href="http://www.kottke.org/03/08/030826standards_do.html">kottke.org</a>  about semantic and structural markup and content.
</p>
<p>
The discussion of semantics vs. structure vs. syntax and validation in *ML took a different turn for me today.  I usually understand the argument of semantical markup vs. structural markup. I must admit though that I've always approached it from the side of layout <em>first</em>, then content second. In other words, if I used &lt;ul&gt; and &lt;li&gt; for menus, it was simply because I <em>should</em> use it instead of a gaggle of &lt;div&gt; tags.
</p>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
<p>
That's ok I thought. It's certainly a step ahead of where I used to be. But I still find myself constantly misusing other tags like &lt;kbd&gt; and &lt;samp&gt;. Why is that? I could be a simple case of lack of practice.  But I also think it's a matter of tagname-&gt;semantics translation.
</p>
<p>
I'm in the proecess of wiriting some API documentation for various projects and just started looking at <a href="http:/www.docbook.org/">DocBook</a>.
Now that I'm focused on writing content first and layering markup on top of it, instead of writing the markup in mind first, it makes me think that part of what causes poor semantic HTML is the tagnames themselves.
</p>
<p>
In HTML I need to highlight the name of a file. Should it be &lt;tt&gt;, &lt;samp&gt;, or &lt;kbd&gt;?  Sometimes it's clear. Sometimes it's not. But in DocBook, it doesn't get more clear than &lt;filename&gt;.
</p>
<p>
I'm now even considering converting the contents of this site into DocBook format.  Rather than struggle with which tag to use, it may turn out to be easier to use tags that are already a little more clear. But that's just me.
</p>
-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: WMA Is Cool. WMP/DirectOutput Sucks
BASENAME: wma-is-cool-wmpdirectoutput-sucks
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: Music
CATEGORY: Music
DATE: 08/29/2003 09:49:53 AM
-----
BODY:
<p>
A while back I <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000259/">praised Windows Media Player</a> for being so good at ripping CDs quickly. Then I also ranted about the WMA format sucking ass because it's <a href="/blog/archives/entries/000263/">skipping randomly</a> on every computer I owned, where my old Ogg Vorbis files did not skip.
</p>
<p>
Well after some more tinkering I've narrowed the problem down to DirectShow and the DirectOutput crap in DirectX. The minute I turned off DirectOutput in WinAmp, the skipping went away. Unfortunately, there doesn't appear to be a way to turn of DirectOutput in WMP, so that player is out of the loop.
</p>
<p>
At this point, I'm starting from scratch, and need to decide to rip WMA or Ogg Vorbis again. WMA is definately faster but since I'm not going to be using WMP for playback and it's library functions, what's the point? Chances are I'm not going to get a portable devies anytime soon, and by them some of them wil already have Ogg Vorbis support.
</p>

AUTHOR: 
TITLE: Chicken Death
BASENAME: chicken-death
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 0
ALLOW PINGS: 0
PRIMARY CATEGORY: OffTopic
CATEGORY: OffTopic
DATE: 09/01/2003 10:13:54 PM
-----
BODY:
<p>
I'm not a great cook, and I say following recipes to the letter is for the birds. With those two things in mind give this "chicken death" a try. Guaranteed for a few hours of misery.
</p>

<ul>
<li>2 packages of Louis Rich fully cooked Southwestern chicken strips</li>
<li>1 diced white onion</li>
<li>1 diced green bell pepper</li>
<li>1 diced red bell pepper</li>
<li>2-3 diced red fresno peppers. bonus points for habaneros instead</li>
<li>salt</li>
<li>pepper</li>
<li>franks redhot sauce</li>
</ul>

<p>
Fry it all together how you like it and melt desired cheese on top. Put sour cream, cheese on a tortilla shell, then the chicken death, then more hot sauce. </p>
<p>
Fold. Eat. Regret.
</p>
